[Nicole Morell]: if we want to keep doing our budgets year after year of tough decisions, of just getting by, of doing more with less, or if we want to do, I don't even want to say more with more, more with enough, more with a good start, where we can do a little bit more for our roads, be able to envision a future of Medford Public Schools and our community where budgets are not based in crisis and cuts, but envision and doing more for our students and for our community.

[Nicole Morell]: be it further resolved that the council adds the following requests to that report.

[Nicole Morell]: One, any issues with the process for filing for a recount and why it took so long for the candidates and the public to be notified.

[Nicole Morell]: Two, any process issues in preparation for the recount.

[Nicole Morell]: And three, what systems will be put in place to ensure prompt and timely notification of any issues or errors to the public to ensure trust is maintained when errors are made.

[Nicole Morell]: the we're looking at that deed restriction understanding there's a lot of ledge in that area my intention in this is not to this is obviously for the future my intention is not to say hey there's no blasting but just understanding that a lot of the issues relating from the Winthrop Street project is that we have nothing on the books as far as regulations and permits and steps that people have to follow when they're actually doing that so making sure we have some steps that make sure that our the

[Nicole Morell]: residents and neighbors in the area aren't disturbed in the way that they were with the Winthrop Street project and it's done in a completely different way that respects our residents and make sure that we have permits approvals and process in place to make this a much better experience should it go forward in any place in the city than what happened on Winthrop Street.

[Nicole Morell]: I said that.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a funny position to like calling people to say nice things.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: save it out for last.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Sen.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Former Councilor Marks.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm keeping everyone engaged.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Nicole Morell]: I really appreciate you coming up and saying some kind words and some true words.

[Nicole Morell]: And hopefully now that we're both out of office, I won't get so nervous every time I see you either sitting there or approaching the podium.

[Nicole Morell]: So one last time, I appreciate it.

[Nicole Morell]: I want to thank everyone for their kind words.

[Nicole Morell]: I truly love this job and there are times that I think I'm not half bad at it.

[Nicole Morell]: There are times I think I'm terrible at it and there are times I think I'm great, but they all even out in the end.

[Nicole Morell]: So deciding not to run this year was one of the hardest decisions I've probably ever had to make.

[Nicole Morell]: I think as comes through on the council is I usually

[Nicole Morell]: know exactly how I feel about something.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm always listening, but I usually know how I feel.

[Nicole Morell]: I know how I'm going to go.

[Nicole Morell]: And this is something that I really wrestled with for months and probably, honestly, the better part of two years.

[Nicole Morell]: But like everyone in these seats, I also have a full time job.

[Nicole Morell]: and I have a favorite constituent who is just about two years old and who has shared his whole life with this council.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm stepping away to spend more time with him in those early precious years, which I know you all know, but I think, again, without the lack of paper and all these things, sometimes that's information that hasn't been shared.

[Nicole Morell]: I care about this job.

[Nicole Morell]: I love this job.

[Nicole Morell]: I care about my son.

[Nicole Morell]: I love my son.

[Nicole Morell]: I want to spend some time with him.

[Nicole Morell]: You know, there's a saying in parenting that the days are long, but the years are short, which I know all the parents here will agree with.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think I'd like to extend that to city council where the meetings are long, but the years are short.

[Nicole Morell]: I can't believe it's been four years.

[Nicole Morell]: I can't believe it's only been four years.

[Nicole Morell]: I can't believe it's been a long four years and it's been a short four years.

[Nicole Morell]: I think starting this whole journey just before the pandemic I know we all have that feeling of time kind of collapsing in on itself and it feels like so long ago I started in this body, but it's only been just a few years.

[Nicole Morell]: We did a lot of great work as a council.

[Nicole Morell]: There's a lot of great work left to be done, a lot of work left to be done.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm not going to go through everything we worked on because this isn't a campaign speech, but there's a lot that I'm proud of.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just want to note that

[Nicole Morell]: We often say that it's a privilege to do this job.

[Nicole Morell]: It's a privilege to represent your peers.

[Nicole Morell]: It's a privilege to serve the public.

[Nicole Morell]: And beyond that, it's also an extreme privilege to have the opportunity to meet and strike up conversations with and friendships with people that simply wouldn't happen if you didn't have the access and the welcome that this role gives you.

[Nicole Morell]: And so I think every person that I've spoken with for that, whether we agreed or not, the ability to sit down with someone or pick up a phone call and have a conversation with something has been a privilege and really a gift.

[Nicole Morell]: And another gift, which, you know, there are nights

[Nicole Morell]: I can't believe I'm saying this, but it's all of you behind the rails.

[Nicole Morell]: I think there's something going on in this body since, you know, I think the past two years in particular that there's a camaraderie and a respect that I think we all know is

[Nicole Morell]: quickly or has already left much of politics, but I think it's still alive and well behind the rail where, as has been said, we all don't agree a lot of times.

[Nicole Morell]: It gets heated sometimes, but I think at the end of the day we know there's a deep respect.

[Nicole Morell]: There's usually, you know, after some of our, even during some of our most challenging meetings,

[Nicole Morell]: there's a time where we can have a few jokes and let out some of that tension and remember that we all respect each other and no one here holds a grudge.

[Nicole Morell]: I want to say very briefly about people going around the room.

[Nicole Morell]: I've already said my nice things about Rick and Adam, but Justin, it's been a pleasure to serve with you and just to have your cerebral and considerate approach to everything and also have a resident Harvard man.

[Nicole Morell]: Kit, you are the epitome of speak softly and carry a big stick.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think everyone learned that one or two budgets ago.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's just been so good for my soul to have another woman on the council that I can kind of just look at sometimes or catch a smile from in those heavy meetings.

[Nicole Morell]: George, I think it may have taken us a longer path than some to get to that place of friendship, but we got there.

[Nicole Morell]: And I truly respect you.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just, we've been able to have some conversations this term in particular, just to say, Hey, you know, I don't agree with you on this, but I want you to know it's no hard feelings.

[Nicole Morell]: And I know you're doing what you think you believe is right.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think that's a, it's a two way street and I really respect you.

[Nicole Morell]: And vice president Bears, when I was first running and working really hard, someone pulled papers on the very last day and I thought, who is this Zach Bears?

[Nicole Morell]: Why is he trying to ruin me?

[Nicole Morell]: And the answer over to that, who is this Zach Bears, is he's a friend, he's a confidant, he's someone who, when I had a one week old, a one month old, a one year old, allowed me to be in this position as president, who helped me with some of the logistics and all those things that go on behind the scene and allowed me to serve and fulfill this role and chair the body as I was home with a little tiny newborn for those first eight weeks.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a demanding job.

[Nicole Morell]: It's a fulfilling job.

[Nicole Morell]: It's so important and I'm so thankful to the residents who put me into this position, giving me the opportunity to do this.

[Nicole Morell]: I hope you remember me if I decide to come back and

[Nicole Morell]: I'm not going to make Rick's mistake, but I thank my family who allowed me to be here.

[Nicole Morell]: I think one of the, I knew I would have the logistical support to be here.

[Nicole Morell]: I thank my husband for that.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, but emotionally it's really hard and everyone makes that sacrifice, you know, Tuesday, Wednesday, all the nights, all the mornings, all the phone calls.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, and right now I want to spend that time with my son, but I do want to say farewell and thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: And I'm not sure what my next move is, but for better or worse, I can assure you, you are not rid of me yet.

[Nicole Morell]: I thank you all.

[Nicole Morell]: All right, it was Zach's fault.

[Nicole Morell]: He said it was gonna be short.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Vice President Bears, seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: All those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: Aye.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Simply reaching for equity of pay seems like an overreach.

[Nicole Morell]: 23462, to Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding grant agreement with The Trees Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear Madam President and councillors, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following order.

[Nicole Morell]: Order is sponsored by Burano-Window-Current Mayor.

[Nicole Morell]: In order authorizing a grant agreement between the city and Trees Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Summary, the order will authorize the mayor to enter into a grant agreement with Trees Medford in accordance with the provisions of General Law Chapter 44, Section 53A, pursuant to which Trees Medford will provide a grant of funds towards continuing efforts to create and maintain a public tree inventory for the city in consultation with the tree warden.

[Nicole Morell]: be ordered by the City Council of the City of Medford Assembled and by the authority of the same as follows, whereas the City of Trees Medford wish to continue urban forestry efforts throughout the City and whereas Trees Medford has expressed interest in providing a grant in the amount of

[Nicole Morell]: $12,500 to the City in support of the services necessary to continue the public tree inventory throughout the City, and whereas, pursuant to the provisions of General Law, Chapter 44, Section 53A, the City may accept and expend such grant monies with the approval of the Mayor and the City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: Now, therefore, the City Council hereby approves the grant of funds by Trees Medford to the City in support of the services necessary to continue the City's efforts

[Nicole Morell]: with respect to a public tree inventory for the city and authorizes the mayor to execute the grant agreement as attached to and incorporated in this order.

[Nicole Morell]: Respectfully submitted, Brianna Lungocard, Mayor.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Councilor Caraviello to approve a secondary by Crisis Affairs.

[Nicole Morell]: It's a roll call because it's financial.

[Nicole Morell]: to Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding loan order a city with water systems bond.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear President Morell and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order.

[Nicole Morell]: City of Medford loan order water bonds be ordered that the 3,422,000 is appropriated for the purpose of making improvements to the city's water system, including constructing and reconstructing water mains and other costs incidental and related thereto.

[Nicole Morell]: that to meet this appropriation, the treasurer, with the approval of the mayor, is authorized to borrow said amount pursuant to Chapter 44, Section 8.5 of the General Laws, or pursuant to any other enabling authority, and to issue bonds or notes of the city thereafter, that the treasurer, with the approval of the mayor, is authorized to borrow all or a portion of such amount from the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, pursuant to the MWRA's local water systems assistant program, and in connection therewith, to enter into a loan agreement and or financial assistant agreement with the MWRA

[Nicole Morell]: and to accept any grants or the project from the MWRA, provided that the amount of the authorized borrowing shall be reduced by the amount of any such grant received from the MWRA.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion, Vice President Bears to waive the remainder of the reading in favor of summary, seconded by Councilor Carballo.

[Nicole Morell]: All those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: Aye.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: City Engineer Bortella, are you speaking on this or?

[Nicole Morell]: I am.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, if you wanna come up if you wanna

[Nicole Morell]: Tell us about this.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Can't waive the three readings because it's a financial paper, but tonight, ideally.

[Nicole Morell]: So unfortunately, we can't waive the three readings.

[Nicole Morell]: I think we could talk to the clerk about if there's funds to get it posted and advertised faster.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Any questions or discussion from the council?

[Nicole Morell]: And do I have a motion?

[Nicole Morell]: I have a motion from Vice President Bears to approve for first reading, seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, I'm in the affirmative, you're in the negative, the motion passes for first reading.

[Nicole Morell]: 23467, I believe that's my paper, so I will go in first to the chair, so vice president Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: So first, I'd like to amend my letter if I could, Mr. Clerk, for the record.

[Nicole Morell]: My language was not clear.

[Nicole Morell]: Though the school committee has largely been women for the better part of a decade, it was more evenly split before that.

[Nicole Morell]: However, my statement stands about the makeup of the city council and how hard it is for women to break in there.

[Nicole Morell]: Only a small number of women have ever served on the city council in Medford's history, with two more joining in January.

[Nicole Morell]: I would have meant to strike both references from the whereas if I could, thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Historically, the school committee has been the only elected body where women could serve while city council remains majority men to this day.

[Nicole Morell]: Going back more than a hundred years ago, there've been multiple women on school committee in Medford, whereas the city council has been almost exclusively men until more recent history.

[Nicole Morell]: Historically, school committees have been paid less and valued less than that of city council statewide, countrywide as an accepted fact.

[Nicole Morell]: One reason I brought forth this resolution is to interrogate that fact.

[Nicole Morell]: School committee has many statutory powers outlined at the state level.

[Nicole Morell]: They play an essential role in the city, a role that's getting more involved and more complicated in the current political climate.

[Nicole Morell]: And like many city Councilors, they're on call essentially 24 seven.

[Nicole Morell]: But yet this body has always been seen and continues to be seen as less than.

[Nicole Morell]: One reason to me comes from a conversation I've had many times with my mother, a 35 year public school teacher.

[Nicole Morell]: is that the school committee is an extension of the schools.

[Nicole Morell]: Schools and teaching are seen as women's work, largely because it's one of the few ways women could gain employment.

[Nicole Morell]: In a country where we undervalue or often do not value women's work, be it caregiving roles, aides, paras, teachers, social workers, nurses, and the like, regardless of who is serving in these roles, men or women, we do not value them in the way that we should.

[Nicole Morell]: This is not to equate any of these positions as they are very different.

[Nicole Morell]: I absolutely understand that and believe that.

[Nicole Morell]: But it is to note that when we undervalue work for a long time, changing the financials and the mindset around it becomes hard.

[Nicole Morell]: Simply reaching for equity of pay seems like an overreach.

[Nicole Morell]: Equity of opportunity is another important reason I brought this forward.

[Nicole Morell]: This resolution is about who's not in the room.

[Nicole Morell]: I've been to many trainings and brainstorms where folks struggle with how to bring diversity of experiences and voices to the table in many, many spaces.

[Nicole Morell]: Diversity, which has been proven to make boards and organizations more successful.

[Nicole Morell]: It's something we struggle with here, but it's not unique to Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: The one answer that always comes back in these brainstorms and these thought projects is paying folks for their time.

[Nicole Morell]: I've spoken with many folks in Medford who want to be more involved, but it doesn't make financial sense for them to get a babysitter to attend a school committee meeting, let alone commit to multiple years of pay that barely covers the cost of childcare or loss of learnings they would need to cover regular meetings, negotiating meetings, grievances, executive sessions, and the day-to-day essential role of responding to residents.

[Nicole Morell]: By saying we don't value this position, we say we don't value the insight, experiences, and representation of folks who do not have the financial support and caregiver support that is needed to give to these roles.

[Nicole Morell]: This excludes folks doing shift work, folks who need two jobs to get by, people without free or low cost childcare.

[Nicole Morell]: No one does these jobs, these elected jobs for the pay, but the lack of it certainly keeps many folks from seeking them and having a representative body.

[Nicole Morell]: I've been having these conversations long before I even ran for council, so I wanted to bring this forward before the end of my term.

[Nicole Morell]: This equity discussion is important to me, and equity delayed is equity denied.

[Nicole Morell]: However,

[Nicole Morell]: I absolutely do hear you, and I really want to thank the folks who have reached out to me on email over the past few days.

[Nicole Morell]: I appreciate those just willing to hear what I have to say.

[Nicole Morell]: I understand your feelings, absolutely.

[Nicole Morell]: And I know there are many folks eager to talk tonight, and I'm eager to hear from you.

[Nicole Morell]: So reflecting on this, I would further amend this paper that I would hope for a phase-in over time to either these amounts or amounts that reflect similar cost of living increases to the council or other city employees over the past 24 years.

[Nicole Morell]: nearly two and a half decades where there were no such adjustments for the school committee.

[Nicole Morell]: Also understanding it's the end of my term, as I did not seek reelection to spend more time with my almost two year old, a testament to the trade offs of these types of jobs.

[Nicole Morell]: My motion is to send this to the committee the whole so that the incoming council may consider it if they so choose and explore what they would like based on the conversations we have here tonight and ongoing conversations.

[Nicole Morell]: So I thank you for your time.

[Nicole Morell]: I thank you for your respect as I share this tonight.

[Nicole Morell]: I know it's a topic that people feel very, very strongly about, and I absolutely understand.

[Nicole Morell]: And I thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: Point of information, it's the way Zoom works, there's like a lot of sound, it cuts out.

[Nicole Morell]: I just have a brief point of information.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to note that no money has been moved anywhere just at this point.

[Nicole Morell]: No vote has been taken.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to make sure that's clear, because I understand the intent of what you said.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to make sure that's clear, because that happened.

[Nicole Morell]: I do just want to thank Ms.

[Nicole Morell]: Douglas for bringing that forward about the PFMLA.

[Nicole Morell]: I wasn't aware of that fact.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears and I actually introduced a resolution

[Nicole Morell]: two years ago about extending PFMLA to the entire city.

[Nicole Morell]: And we were essentially rebuffed by the administration about it being a possibility.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's really helpful for me to know that that is continuing on.

[Nicole Morell]: It's something that still is on our books.

[Nicole Morell]: It's nothing that's been disposed of.

[Nicole Morell]: So I hope that the next council will continue the conversation around it.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: I'll let you know how to remember.

[Nicole Morell]: I'll teach you.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to thank everyone for coming out and taking the time to speak.

[Nicole Morell]: Obviously, my intention was never to submit this, and to be inflammatory, my intention was to start a conversation.

[Nicole Morell]: But I think what's come out of this conversation is so much that we don't get to hear on city council.

[Nicole Morell]: We get the school budget delivered to us as such.

[Nicole Morell]: We're not at the bargaining table because we can't be.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think this really illuminates a lot of issues that they either come to us when the budget is already set in stone, or we simply just never hear about them.

[Nicole Morell]: So I really, really appreciate the time.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm sorry I won't be there to continue the conversations, at least in this role.

[Nicole Morell]: But I think a lot of important things

[Nicole Morell]: were shared tonight and I do just want to make it explicit that I never introduced this as in insult or to say that the jobs are equal to paraprofessional and the school committee.

[Nicole Morell]: I noted before my mom taught in a poor school district for 35 years special education and I know how essential

[Nicole Morell]: her powers were to the success of her classrooms.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just know how much she had to fight and how much she had to put up with and how much I think she's thankful that she retired in 2011 because your jobs are so incredibly difficult and more multifaceted and challenging than they ever have been before.

[Nicole Morell]: And

[Nicole Morell]: believe me or not, but I am so, so appreciative of the work you do.

[Nicole Morell]: And I thank you for taking the time to come out tonight, knowing you already put in a full day that is exhausting.

[Nicole Morell]: I watched my mother come home after work and just kind of pass it on the bed.

[Nicole Morell]: I know how hard your day was.

[Nicole Morell]: So I just want to make that clear again, believe me or not, but I just want to state that.

[Nicole Morell]: So thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: So, I believe we are back from recess.

[Nicole Morell]: I know I motion to revert to regular business.

[Nicole Morell]: Someone would like to revert?

[Nicole Morell]: We have someone from public participation that I thought had left and he has been here the entire time and I feel like we should take him.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion by Susan Baird to suspend the real estate public participation is seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Aye.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Notice of a public hearing, Medford City Council, Chapter 94, Zoning.

[Nicole Morell]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on Tuesday, December 12th, 2023 at 7 p.m.

[Nicole Morell]: in the City Council Chamber on the second floor

[Nicole Morell]: of Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford Mass, 02155, and via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to a proposed amendment to the City of Medford zoning ordinance and zoning map.

[Nicole Morell]: A Zoom link to this meeting will be posted no later than December 8, 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: The purpose of the amendment is to comply with Section 3A of MGL-40A MBTA Community Zoning Law by establishing a new zoning overlay within a half-mile radius of the Wellington MBTA Orange Line station that will allow multifamily housing and mixed-use development as of right.

[Nicole Morell]: A copy of the full text of the amendment is available in the office of the city clerk and on the city's website www.medfordma.org slash department slash planning dash development dash sustainability by clicking on current city board filings.

[Nicole Morell]: So what brings us here tonight is after completing...

[Nicole Morell]: the recodification work that we had engaged with Attorney Bobrowski over two years to do that work that was completed actually last March.

[Nicole Morell]: 23-314, Committee of the Whole, meeting Tuesday, December 5th, 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: It's called to order.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Present. 5 present, 2 absent, and the meeting is called to order.

[Nicole Morell]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Committee of the Whole on Tuesday, December 5, 2023 at 6 p.m.

[Nicole Morell]: in the Medford City Council Chamber on the second floor of Medford City Hall via Zoom.

[Nicole Morell]: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss Paper 23-314, Private Ways in the City of Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: The City Council has invited DPW Commissioner Tim McGibbon and Attorneys Robin Stein and Sharon Everett of KP Law to attend this meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: For further information, aids, and accommodations, contact the City Clerk at 781-393-2425.

[Nicole Morell]: Sincerely yours, Nicole Morell, Council President.

[Nicole Morell]: So as the meeting notice states, this is actually from a paper from Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: We've had a number of these papers over the years, honestly, usually multiple during the year, regarding questions that residents will have as far as services on private ways,

[Nicole Morell]: some of it stemming from impetus as far as in saying they used to have a certain service on their private way, they no longer have it, or understanding why they don't have a service, things like that.

[Nicole Morell]: We have had some subcommittee meetings on this where we've had Commissioner McGivern explain a lot of the role that the DPW takes on, but much of this actually enters the legal area as far as what is allowed under Massachusetts general law for practices on private ways.

[Nicole Morell]: So as such,

[Nicole Morell]: We have attorneys Everett and Stein from KP Law with us tonight.

[Nicole Morell]: I know we have a number of questions.

[Nicole Morell]: I will do my best to address Councilor Scarpelli's questions from my memory as we're here.

[Nicole Morell]: And then, so we'll just kick things off.

[Nicole Morell]: Attorney Everett or Stein, can you hear us?

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Attorney Everett can hear us at least, so.

[Nicole Morell]: Before, I know I have a number of questions if Councilors have any questions that they would like to ask.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Vice President Paris.

[Nicole Morell]: Attorney Stein, Attorney Everett, is that something you would be able to provide?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: One question I had I actually got from a resident.

[Nicole Morell]: So you talked about, I think, the ability of

[Nicole Morell]: all I think you said, it has to be every abutter on a private way has to agree.

[Nicole Morell]: Could residents on a private way, I'm not an abutter, but residents, could residents on a private way, if everyone on the street agreed, could they put like a speed hump on their road?

[Nicole Morell]: Or does that exist in some other plane of regulation?

[Nicole Morell]: Sorry, can you hear me now?

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: No, they can't hear us, Kevin.

[Nicole Morell]: It's just faint.

[Nicole Morell]: Can you hear me now?

[Nicole Morell]: OK, so could I had a question from a resident that asked if they got everyone on their private way to agree, could they actually install a speed hump on their private way or does that exist under some other regulation?

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: And not that anyone is asking this.

[Nicole Morell]: So just making sure I'm understanding that kind of the way that, you know, every level up from the city is what Trump's like MGL, Trump, you know, you follow MGL and then city law and federal kind of that thing.

[Nicole Morell]: We can't, people couldn't suddenly say, we want our private way to have a 55 mile per hour speed limit.

[Nicole Morell]: And that, you know, just making sure that the city regulations apply first.

[Nicole Morell]: And then if folks want to work within that city regulation to make some changes to their street, they can.

[Nicole Morell]: or city ordinances apply first?

[Nicole Morell]: I'm just saying, so I guess another way to phrase it is like, we can't make an ordinance in Medford that supersedes or goes, supersedes MGL.

[Nicole Morell]: And MGL can't make a, you know, the state house can't pass a law that supersedes federal law.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm just saying that the-

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, so private way folks can't make some law that is outside of or some regulation that is outside of city ordinances.

[Nicole Morell]: All city ordinances still apply.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think actually a lot of the questions we get are related to services.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think regulation, I think that makes sense.

[Nicole Morell]: I think where folks get confused, understandably so, is

[Nicole Morell]: you know, they're told they have a, they know they live on a private way and outside of the fact that we all pay the same taxes regardless of what type of street we live on, they get some city services.

[Nicole Morell]: So the street may be plowed or there may be, you know, if sometimes when branches fall into the road, like large branches, they may be picked up, things like that.

[Nicole Morell]: If folks request a stop sign, it gets installed.

[Nicole Morell]: So where's the line there as far as services that cities with private ways

[Nicole Morell]: can or do provide and then ones that would be going outside and would be deemed using public funds for private goods?

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, and could you, you were hard to hear a little bit before, could you repeat back the section of MGL that was adopted, opted into for that?

[Nicole Morell]: So an example for that, I have a very specific example, is that on a private way, it just has a catchment basin that, because of increased rain events, it's just overflowing.

[Nicole Morell]: there wouldn't be really anything that the city could do to fix that, because that needs a complete overhaul.

[Nicole Morell]: It needs to be likely tied into the city sewer to avoid that problem.

[Nicole Morell]: And that would not be considered a temporary repair.

[Nicole Morell]: That would be a permanent.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm going to go to Commissioner Gabert.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: But folks have said, folks who have been in their home for a really long time, we had a specific example of someone saying that the city donated a tree, they planted a tree in front of my house on a private way before I was the owner of the house, I didn't ask for this tree, and now it's damaging the sidewalk in front of the house.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Paris.

[Nicole Morell]: Are there any other questions from Councilors at this time?

[Nicole Morell]: I see a resident or two on the call, so I want to make sure we get to them if they have questions.

[Nicole Morell]: Seeing none, if there's any folks on the Zoom who have a question, please raise your hand.

[Nicole Morell]: I don't see any at this time, so I'll go back to one more very specific scenario.

[Nicole Morell]: I probably know the answer.

[Nicole Morell]: So if we have one of the trees that we think the city planted at some point on a private way, it comes down and it, you know, damages a piece of property on the private way.

[Nicole Morell]: That is not the, our reading of the law is that that is not the city's responsibility.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: That's correct.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Great.

[Nicole Morell]: Any other questions at this time?

[Nicole Morell]: 23-450 offered by President Morell, Vice President Bears, and Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the Elections Commission and Elections Manager provide a report to the Council listing any and all issues or procedural errors that occurred during the administration of the 2023 municipal election.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it further resolved that the report includes specific responses to, one, the misprinting of ballots, two, the inaccurate instruction sheets provided to voters with mail ballots, three, the trainings that provided incorrect information to poll wardens,

[Nicole Morell]: and workers regarding voters bringing materials to assist them in the voting booth, and four, persistent issues with the counting of ballots in a timely manner and release of incomplete, unofficial election results to the public.

[Nicole Morell]: For the result, the mayor provided the council with a supplemental appropriation request to restore the full-time staffing levels in the election department.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Do we have to take a roll call on that?

[Nicole Morell]: So we have a motion for Vice-President Bears to join 23-450 and 23-451.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the election coordinator report back to the city council with a detailed report and findings detailing the municipal election, which includes, but is not limited to absentee ballots, polling rules and regulations and complaints and malfunction.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm going to go on order as far as the names of the papers.

[Nicole Morell]: So the vice mayors, Councilor Carbello, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor say.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to make it very clear, I believe my fellow councilors have covered pretty much everything.

[Nicole Morell]: I do just want to note that elections are objectively more complicated these days.

[Nicole Morell]: There's early voting, there's permanent mail ballots, there's election day voting, and

[Nicole Morell]: The council, I think, really under the request and advisement of our previous elections coordinator, moved to that commission format to streamline this process.

[Nicole Morell]: And unfortunately, as a result, that commission and that office, well, not the commission, but the office was understaffed.

[Nicole Morell]: And this is something that council pointed out time and time again.

[Nicole Morell]: We asked for that office to be staffed up, and it was not heard.

[Nicole Morell]: So we did one thing, and then we got a negative outcome from it, because the

[Nicole Morell]: the mayor's end was not upheld essentially from our wishes.

[Nicole Morell]: So again, I think just want to make both those things clear that there is a lot of moving pieces.

[Nicole Morell]: There are more moving pieces than there ever have been in our elections or local elections.

[Nicole Morell]: And we made a change that was asked for and we believe would absolutely streamline and make this process easier, but without the staffing.

[Nicole Morell]: It doesn't work, so I appreciate Vice President Bears bringing that up, as well as the appropriation for that staffing that we've been asking for this whole time.

[Nicole Morell]: 23-411, notice of a public hearing, Medford City Council, Chapter 94, Zone 8.

[Nicole Morell]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on November 14, 2023 at 7 p.m.

[Nicole Morell]: in the Medford City Council Chamber on the second floor of Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Mass, 02155, and via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to paper 23-411.

[Nicole Morell]: also known as paper 23-407, a petition by the Medford Housing Authority to amend zoning map city of Medford, Mass., dated April 13, 1965, as referenced in Medford Zoning Ordinance Chapter 94-2.2.

[Nicole Morell]: The amendment proposes to change the zoning district designation of the property of 1-20 Waffling Court as depicted on sheets 1-6 of the plans entitled

[Nicole Morell]: ALTA NSPS land title survey prepared by Fuss and O'Neill and dated February 6, 2022 from apartment one zoning district to a planned development district, which would have a new development standard per Medford zoning ordinance chapter 94-9.2.3.

[Nicole Morell]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be posted no later than November 10th, 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: For additional information, aids and accommodations, call the Medford City Clerk's Office at 781-393-2425, TDD 781-393-2516.

[Nicole Morell]: The full materials of the amendment can be viewed

[Nicole Morell]: in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103, or on the city's website at medfordma.org, slash department, slash planning, dash development, dash sustainability, by clicking on current city board filings.

[Nicole Morell]: Advertised in the Medford Transcript and Somerville Journal, September 14th and 21st, 2023, by order of the Medford city clerk, signed Adam L. Hurtubise, city clerk.

[Nicole Morell]: We do have the petitioner here.

[Nicole Morell]: Just for an update on this process, this has been many months of public meetings.

[Nicole Morell]: I think we have had a number of committees of the whole on this, some by statute that we had to have, some we just had as informational.

[Nicole Morell]: This was reported out to the CD board and their recommendation was, I believe it was 5-0.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tsengh, and thank you to you and Councilor Collins for sponsoring this with me.

[Nicole Morell]: The Transgender Day of Remembrance came after the result of the murders of two black transgender women in Alston and Watertown, so very close.

[Nicole Morell]: I mean, it just speaks to it being in our backyard.

[Nicole Morell]: Sometimes I think we think living in an area like this, it's not something that's faced by the community, but of course it is.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think that Councilor Tseng's point, this really highlights the intersectionality of the issue.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think it's important this year, it's important every year.

[Nicole Morell]: But as you know, we have record-breaking numbers of transgender, anti-transgender legislation being presented across the country.

[Nicole Morell]: That has very real impacts because of the legislation, but because it further others this community and lets people look at them as different and people that they should not treat with the dignity and respect they deserve like the rest of us.

[Nicole Morell]: So if in small part we can bring this forward from the city council, say we remember, say this is important, that I'm glad we can do that.

[Nicole Morell]: in the Medford City Council Chambers on the second floor of Medford City Hall and via Zoom.

[Nicole Morell]: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss proposed food truck ordinance per paper 20-020.

[Nicole Morell]: The committee has invited Interim Economic Development Director Victor Schrader and Attorney Robert Stein of KP Law to attend this meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: For further information, aids, and accommodations, contact the city clerk.

[Nicole Morell]: at 781-393-2425.

[Nicole Morell]: Sincerely yours, Nicole Morel, Council President.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is an ordinance that we last visited in February of this year.

[Nicole Morell]: This is something that has been a policy that was put into place, I believe, in 2016 by then-Mayor Burke, and this whole process has been essentially streamlining that policy and really just bringing it into ordinance form, so there's no questions as far as how these permits are

[Nicole Morell]: quite forgotten and things like that.

[Nicole Morell]: At our last meeting we left it and that we wanted to pass this on through Interim Director Schrader to get additional feedback from the Board of Health as well as Fire and Police and Engineering, I believe.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: I think, yeah, just to build on, I don't see any councilors talking at the moment.

[Nicole Morell]: To build on what Vice Mayor Bears and Councilor Scarpelli said, yeah, I think our intent was very much to just take the policy that was in place, make sure it's streamlined, and make sure it's very explicit in an ordinance, the steps that need to be gone through.

[Nicole Morell]: and of course deferring to the Board of Health for those approvals because as Councilor Scarpelli said, sometimes these come before us, they might come before us late, someone might realize they need it for an event on Wednesday, we don't need it again until the next week, so I think it's just taking this and moving it to the Board of Health which already sees these permits and just making them the deciding authority on it.

[Nicole Morell]: So I don't think, or I know, based on past conversations, we weren't looking to go into

[Nicole Morell]: zoning and all this stuff and multi-day permits, I think, by design.

[Nicole Morell]: We really wanted to focus on special permits at this time because that's what we felt comfortable about.

[Nicole Morell]: We added the provision as far as how far away from a brick and mortar.

[Nicole Morell]: These food trucks need to be parked and things like that, but it really was to simplify it.

[Nicole Morell]: Announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports and records 23-441 offered by President Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it so resolved that the Medford City Council congratulate Henry and Evelyn Miller on being named 70th anniversary honorees by the Arc of Massachusetts.

[Nicole Morell]: Henry and Evelyn have long worked with the Arc and for more than 50 years have advocated for and worked to improve the lives of individuals, intellectual and developmental disabilities and their families.

[Nicole Morell]: I introduced this resolution, but I'm happy to have if there's any other Councilors wanna speak first.

[Nicole Morell]: resolution on the Miller and family.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm also I'll just go.

[Nicole Morell]: I put this on a resident actually brought this to my attention as everyone who knows Henry and Evelyn there's no shortage of causes they're involved in in the city, they dedicate a lot of time their, their time to the city.

[Nicole Morell]: as well as to the Arc of Massachusetts and specifically individuals and families that are affected by intellectual and developmental disabilities.

[Nicole Morell]: So they're being honored by the Arc of Massachusetts as they celebrate 70 years.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think that's just a testament to all the work they've done for this community and all the work they continue to do and their dedication.

[Nicole Morell]: And I wanna thank the resident who brought this to my attention because there's no shortage of accolades for Henry and Evelyn.

[Nicole Morell]: So I appreciate them bringing this to my attention as well.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Can I have a motion?

[Nicole Morell]: I introduced it, so I just need a motion.

[Nicole Morell]: Motions, orders and resolutions 23-442 offered by Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Resolved by the Medford City Council that the Traffic Commission review ways to reduce the speed and volume of traffic using Willis Avenue as a cut through, including but not limited to directing one-way traffic away from Willis Avenue and toward Mystic Avenue and Main Street.

[Nicole Morell]: The addition of speed tables and any other design changes that were discouraged cut through traffic.

[Nicole Morell]: be it further resolved that the Director of Traffic and Transportation provide the Council with information regarding any existing traffic flow studies for the area, or any plans to adjust traffic patterns to reduce cut-through trips.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Harris.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Falco.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, and just from the chair appreciate bears bringing this up and just my fellow Councilors comments on this because I think, as we know, this is a multifaceted issue and I really appreciate the focus on looking citywide I think that's absolutely the approach we should take and I'm sure it's.

[Nicole Morell]: at least in part happening already.

[Nicole Morell]: But I think like so many of our issues, there is a facet of this that is at the state level, we're dealing with a deeply broken public transit system, that people they would be on the T, you know, or they wouldn't take the bus, but they're sitting in the traffic on the bus, and the T doesn't run.

[Nicole Morell]: So you have people that are dealing with return to office.

[Nicole Morell]: You have people who can't take the train.

[Nicole Morell]: So we have more cars than ever on our roads.

[Nicole Morell]: They're backing up and they're looking for ways to cut around.

[Nicole Morell]: And we have the technology and we have the Uber Eats and we have it's, you know, it's a perfect storm.

[Nicole Morell]: And it comes from everywhere.

[Nicole Morell]: It backs up to Winchester because, you know, it comes out of Uber and it comes through, you know, everywhere is inching down the line as you get closer and closer to city center and we just stop moving.

[Nicole Morell]: So I appreciate the effort to see what we can do.

[Nicole Morell]: um, as a city, but just also recognizing that, um, the density of our community and even more so as we'll talk about the rest of this year, in part relies on a public transit system that has not been functioning for a long time.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's embarrassing.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Do you want to hit that button?

[Nicole Morell]: I mean, I can hear you, the people on TV can't hear you.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the City Council discuss a message received from the Chief of Staff regarding extra election ballots mailed to residents' homes.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli, and I'll get to other councils.

[Nicole Morell]: I did reach out to elections manager Melissa Ripley, and she's recovering from surgery, so she couldn't attend, but she did send me, I had some questions myself, just some basic information.

[Nicole Morell]: So she did apologize for not being able to be here tonight, and she stated that 5,100 ballots were sent out over the course of two days,

[Nicole Morell]: At this point, the percentage of voters affected is less than 1%.

[Nicole Morell]: The commission is reviewing the process to ensure that they're putting stopgaps in place to avoid this situation in the future, and they will be reviewing all batches of printed label to ensure that voters only receive one ballot.

[Nicole Morell]: For voters that receive two ballots, you can either shred one or you can drop the extra ballot, and the ballot collection has been located outside of City Hall or outside of the Election Commission's office.

[Nicole Morell]: The State Election Division has a robust computer database that assigns each voter a unique ID.

[Nicole Morell]: When casting a ballot, if a voter were to send in two ballots, only one ballot would be counted.

[Nicole Morell]: The other ballot would be rejected, and it would be filed accordingly.

[Nicole Morell]: She says, we want to assure the voters that our job is to provide the residents and candidates with a fair and equitable election.

[Nicole Morell]: Going to Councilor Collins, then Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Communications from the Mayor, 23-438, to Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding accelerated new growth.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear President Morell and members of the City Council, I respect the request and recommend that your honorable body accept the provisions of Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 59, Section 2A, which provides that any improvements to real estate during the period beginning January 2nd and ending on June 30th of the fiscal year, preceding that to which the tax relates, shall be deemed part of such real property on the January 1st assessment date for that year effective as of fiscal year 2025.

[Nicole Morell]: Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 59, Section 2AA,

[Nicole Morell]: is a local option statute that allows a community to value and assess new growth, example, new construction, or other physical additions to real property occurring by June 30th for the fiscal year beginning July 1st.

[Nicole Morell]: This local adoption law, commonly referred to as Chapter 653, allows the community to assess improved parcels, which ensures the property owners pay a fair share of the cost of government operations for the fiscal year beginning July 1st rather than a later date.

[Nicole Morell]: If accepted, the vote will take effect in fiscal year 2025, July 1st, 2024 through June 30th, 2025, which has an assessment date of January 1st, 2024.

[Nicole Morell]: Therefore, any improvements made from January 2nd, 2024 and June 30th, 2024 will be included in the FY 2025 tax assessment.

[Nicole Morell]: Chief Assessor, Ted Costigan, will be present to provide the council with an overview and answer any questions.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Nicole Morell]: Respectfully submitted, Granolongo Kern, Mayor.

[Nicole Morell]: We have Mr. Costa again here, if councillors have any questions.

[Nicole Morell]: I know you were helpful enough to talk to a lot of us in advance, just make sure we understood what was before us tonight, so I appreciate that.

[Nicole Morell]: Any other questions?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: And if I could, so just, I think just repeating back, as I understand what you said and what we had talked about is essentially cuts down a six month lag time, which helps you administratively, but also I feel like would probably be important in a city, cities like ours, where there is a significant amount of new roof and permits pulled, so making sure we're capturing that kind of as quickly as we can, correct?

[Nicole Morell]: Great, thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: So on the motion of Councilor Caraviello to approve, seconded by Councilor Tseng, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, five in the affirmative, zero in the negative, two absent, the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you so much.

[Nicole Morell]: Communications from city officials, 23-439, the election commission respectfully request the following be added to the October 17th city council meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: One, acceptance of the November 7th election warrant, signatures of the council are required.

[Nicole Morell]: to acceptance of police chief designated officers for early voting and election day details.

[Nicole Morell]: Designated the police chief as a decision maker regarding office staffing at the election polling locations.

[Nicole Morell]: Chapter 92, section 72, the select board, board of select midtown council or city council of each city and town in consultation with its elections officers and registrars shall detail a sufficient number of police officers or constables for each building that contains the polling place for one or more precincts at every election therein to preserve order and to protect the election officers and supervisors from any interference,

[Nicole Morell]: with their duties and to aid in enforcing the laws relating to elections.

[Nicole Morell]: I motion to transfer decisions regarding decisions regarding staffing of police officers at polling locations to the chief of police or his designate for all elections going forward.

[Nicole Morell]: Motion second.

[Nicole Morell]: Oh, sorry.

[Nicole Morell]: Just reading.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, five in the affirmative, zero in the negative, two absent.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: The meeting is adjourned.

[Nicole Morell]: district designation of the property 243 Mystic Avenue as depicted on the plan entitled site layout plan dated June 15th, 2023 from commercial to C2 zoning district to a planned development district PDD, which would have new development standards per Medford zoning ordinance chapter 94-9.2.3.

[Nicole Morell]: To Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, regarding District Improvement Financing Program Order, dear President Morell and members of the City Council, I respectfully request

[Nicole Morell]: I respectfully request and recommend your honorable body in accordance with MGL Chapter 40Q to adopt the enclosed order relating to the creation and implementation of a district improvement financing program for Medford Square.

[Nicole Morell]: Alicia Hunt, Director of Planning, Development Sustainability, and Victoria Storrs, President and Founder of Storrs Associates, will be present at the meeting to answer any questions.

[Nicole Morell]: Given City Council Rule 30, the draft ordinance was reviewed by KB Law, and they have approved it as to form.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Nicole Morell]: Sincerely, Brenna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Nicole Morell]: Order that the Medford City Council will hereby vote in accordance with the provisions of General Law Chapter 40Q2.1, approve, create, and implement a District Improvement Financing Plan, also known as a DIF, to encourage increased residential, industrial, and commercial activity within a development district to be designated and known as the Medford Square DIF Development District, a district pursuant to General Law's Chapter 40Q, as shown on the City of Medford Square.

[Nicole Morell]: DIF Master Plan dated October 3rd, 2023,

[Nicole Morell]: on file in the office of the city clerk and presented to the council, quote, the plan, which is incorporated by reference and in connection therewith approve and adopt a development program for the Medford square development district on file in the office of the city clerk for the improvement of the quality of life and physical facilities and infrastructure of such district and create a development program fund consistent with the requirements of general law chapter 40Q and two,

[Nicole Morell]: Approve the Medford Square Diff Invested Revenue District, the IRD, pursuant to general law chapter 40Q, which is approximately 64.4 acres and coterminous with the development district and is comprised of parcels as shown on the map and as listed in attachment one of the above reference document.

[Nicole Morell]: And in connection therewith, approve and adopt an invested revenue district development program for the Medford Square Diff Invested Revenue District.

[Nicole Morell]: And three, set the percentage of the tax increment to be retained to finance the diff according to the plan.

[Nicole Morell]: and four to make such designations and take any additional steps as may be necessary to authorize such diff or administer said program through the mayor and her designee which is the department of planning development and sustainability after signed authorization and five requests through the mayor that the city of medford assessing department establish and certify

[Nicole Morell]: the original assessed value of the taxable property within the boundaries of the district, and on an annual basis, certify the amount by which the assessed value has increased or decreased from the original value, and six, to authorize the mayor to execute agreements and take such additional action as the mayor deems necessary or appropriate.

[Nicole Morell]: Communications from the mayor, 23-401 to Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding proposed ways adjustment for clerical union.

[Nicole Morell]: I respect the request and recommend that the city council approve the following amendments to the revised ordinances, chapter 66, article two,

[Nicole Morell]: City of Medford amendment to revise ordinances, chapter 66, article two, be ordained by the city council of the city of Medford in chapter 66, entitled personnel, article two, entitled reserve.

[Nicole Morell]: The city's classification and compensation plan, formerly included as article two, section 66-31 through 66-40, amend the figures as they presently appear next to the following title by adjusting each to reflect the following percentage wage increase and effective dates, clerical.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective January 1st, 2020, increase the base salary of all clerical union titles by 2%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective January 1st, 2021, increase the base salary of all clerical union titles by 2%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective July 1st, 2021, increase the base salary of all clerical union titles by 1%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective January 1st, 2022, increase the base salary of all clerical union titles by 2%.

[Nicole Morell]: effective January 1st, 2023, increase the base salary of all clerical union titles by 2.5%.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we request that the mayor require the building department and code enforcement to proactively address the rampant violation

[Nicole Morell]: of the short-term rental provisions in the city's zoning ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it further resolved that the city create a direct relationship with major short-term rental companies like Airbnb and VRBO to automatically remove any illegal listings that violate the city's zoning ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, we do have, it does say that if you're renting out, our current ordinance says if you're renting out individual rooms, the owner has to be present.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins and Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion from the council at this time?

[Nicole Morell]: Any members of the public wish to speak?

[Nicole Morell]: So on the motion of, I mean, we'll take public participation.

[Nicole Morell]: So on the motion of vice president affairs, seconded by councilor Collins, Mr. Calderon.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Seven.

[Nicole Morell]: The infernus during the negative emotion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: It's going to public participation.

[Nicole Morell]: Elliot Jockelson of 60 Marshall Street, Medford, with a complaint regarding violations of short term rental regulations on 66 Lyman Ave, Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Subject is urgent addressing violations of short term rental regulations at 66 Lyman Ave.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear Medford City Council members, I hope this message finds you well.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm ready to draw your attention to a matter of considerable concern regarding the property situated at 66 Lyman Ave in Medford Hillside.

[Nicole Morell]: Recent developments have highlighted serious violations of the city's short-term rental code at this location, prompting the need for a thorough examination.

[Nicole Morell]: Key points of concern, I want to emphasize that I have taken proactive measures to address this situation.

[Nicole Morell]: I personally reached out to Medford Code Enforcement Department to report these violations.

[Nicole Morell]: See click issue ID 15172926.

[Nicole Morell]: In response, they promptly conducted an onsite inspection and acknowledged that the apparent violations by issuing an official violation letter to the property owners.

[Nicole Morell]: However, despite these actions, the property continues to function as an apparent illegal lodging establishment.

[Nicole Morell]: At present, the property remains occupied by a substantial number of guests and is fully booked for the upcoming year.

[Nicole Morell]: operational practices and consequences.

[Nicole Morell]: Based on my investigation, it appears that 66 Lyman Ave is operating in a manner resembling an unauthorized boarding house.

[Nicole Morell]: The proprietors, who reside in Winchester, have been renting individual bedrooms through Airbnb since 2020.

[Nicole Morell]: The operational model has resulted in a continuous influx of approximately six new guests each week for over two years.

[Nicole Morell]: The practice raises serious concerns about security and potential health hazards for our community.

[Nicole Morell]: Security risks in our neighborhood.

[Nicole Morell]: Beyond potential code violations, the security risks associated with operating in a legal hotel in a quiet suburban neighborhood are significant.

[Nicole Morell]: The constant turnover of unfamiliar individuals entering and exiting the premises disrupts the tranquility of our community.

[Nicole Morell]: The dynamic presents security concerns that extend beyond the property itself, affecting neighboring houses and streets, the heightened traffic flow, possible disturbances, and the unfamiliarity of temporary occupancy with local safety protocols amplifies these concerns.

[Nicole Morell]: Identifying regulatory barriers, digital evidence listed in CCLX fix report shows that there are several violations of the short-term rental zoning regulations at 66 Lyman Ave.

[Nicole Morell]: It is crucial to investigate potential factors impeding compliance.

[Nicole Morell]: Three key areas of concern include

[Nicole Morell]: Operator's primary residence requirement is a requirement that a short-term rental property serves as the operator's primary residence appears to be compromised as evidenced by the absence of the owner slash operator and the transportation of supplies from an external location.

[Nicole Morell]: Sole renter party mandate, the practice of renting multiple separate bedrooms of distinct groups as indicated by multiple listings for different bedrooms concurrently raises concerns about compliance with the single party rental mandate and guest count limitation.

[Nicole Morell]: The observed operational activity prompts questions

[Nicole Morell]: about adherence to the stipulated guest limits for short-term rentals.

[Nicole Morell]: Impact on local rental dynamics.

[Nicole Morell]: In addition to potential regulatory infractions, there are implications for our local rental dynamics.

[Nicole Morell]: Short-term rental practices have led to substantial disparities in rental rates, while traditional year-long lease for comparable property rents for approximately 3,500 per month, the same property on Airbnb commands around 6,000 per month.

[Nicole Morell]: This trend distorts the local rental market, rendering long-term leases less accessible for residents.

[Nicole Morell]: preservation of our community's well-being.

[Nicole Morell]: As these complexities unfold, it is vital to address the situation promptly.

[Nicole Morell]: Upholding established regulations and safeguarding our community's well-being are paramount.

[Nicole Morell]: I urge you to enforce the new short-term rental codes for 66 Lyman Ave and all other illegal short-term rentals in Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Your thoughtful consideration is highly valued, and I am confident that your appropriate measures will be taken to address this matter in alignment with existing regulations and the best interests of our community.

[Nicole Morell]: Sincerely, Elliot Jockelson, 60 Marshall Street, Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Would you like to come up?

[Nicole Morell]: Just name and address for the record, even though, or just, you can just say name and address.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: That's embarrassing.

[Nicole Morell]: I don't know what you want to call it.

[Nicole Morell]: The campsite was shut down, so there is precedence.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: This is public participation, and I see some folks online with hands up, and I know folks want to speak in person.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm going to go to Eunice on Zoom.

[Nicole Morell]: I will ask you to unmute.

[Nicole Morell]: And thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Name and address for the record, please?

[Nicole Morell]: I guess we did just recently passed the housing stability notification ordinance, which is about providing renters with information they need to know about renting in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm sure there's something we could explore as far as providing new owners information like this that lets them know about regulations as far as short term rentals, directing them to this

[Nicole Morell]: zoning code, something like that.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: We still have an agenda that folks are here for as well.

[Nicole Morell]: So I will be enforcing the council rules, five minutes each for public participation.

[Nicole Morell]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Nicole Morell]: We are going to be holding as committee of the whole next Tuesday with the executive director of Medford Housing Authority on this project to get an update, to hear from residents and address concerns.

[Nicole Morell]: For the procedures outlined in section 94-9.2 PDD of the Medford zoning ordinance, the applicant 243 Mystic Ave LLC submitted a proposed amendment PDD for the site located at 243 Mystic Ave, Medford-Mass 02155, assessor's map T-10-70B as shown on the locus map PDD2.

[Nicole Morell]: The property is located in a commercial 2C2 zoning district.

[Nicole Morell]: The applicant proposes zoning to align with prospective project, which would include an eight-story structure with life science lab and office uses.

[Nicole Morell]: The Community Development Board has held a public hearing on August 2nd, 2023, notice in accordance with MGL Chapter 40A, Section 11.

[Nicole Morell]: Though not required, a courtesy notice was sent out to abutters within 400 feet of the site in accordance with MGL Chapter 44, Section 53G,

[Nicole Morell]: and the Community Development Board rule regarding consultant fees, the City retained legal counsel, Attorney Gareth Orsmond of Pierce Atwood LLC, to prepare the text of the amendment and provide associated legal support to staff and the board.

[Nicole Morell]: As the Community Development Board voted unanimously to submit the proposed zoning amendment per Medford Zoning Ordinance Section 94-9.2.3.2 to the City Council to initiate the statutory requirements for amending zoning.

[Nicole Morell]: per MGL chapter 48, section five, the zoning amendment now must be referred from city council to the community development board, who will hold a duly noticed public hearing.

[Nicole Morell]: The city council will hold a subsequent public hearing for this amendment after a report with recommendations by the community development board has been submitted to the council.

[Nicole Morell]: Going to paper communications from the mayor 23-388.

[Nicole Morell]: To Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding proposed wage adjustment for DPW union.

[Nicole Morell]: I respectfully request and recommend that the city council approve the following amendments to the revised ordinance chapter 66 article to see Medford amendment to revise ordinances chapter 66 article to be ordained by the city council of the city of Medford in chapter 66.

[Nicole Morell]: Entitled Personnel, Article Two, Entitled Reserve, the city's classification and compensation plan, formerly included as Article Two, Section 6631 through 6640, amend the figures as they presently appear next to the following title by adjusting each to reflect the following percentage wage increases and effective dates.

[Nicole Morell]: DPW, effective July 1st, 2022, increase the base salary of all DPW union titles by 2.5%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective July 1st, 2023, increase the base salary of all DPW union titles by 2.5%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective July 1st, 2024, increase the base salary of all DPW union titles by 3%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective July 1st, 2025, increase the base salary of all DPW union titles by 2.5%.

[Nicole Morell]: Effective July 1st, 2026, increase the base salary of all DPW union titles by 2.5%.

[Nicole Morell]: The following department heads will be available to answer any questions.

[Nicole Morell]: Human Resources Director, Lisa Crowley, and Finance Director slash Auditor, Bob Dickinson.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas our community values, embraces, and celebrates diversity in all its forms.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas Disability Pride Month is recognized each year in July to highlight the accomplishments, work, and advocacy of individuals with disabilities.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas our community is enriched by the contributions, perspectives, and presence of people with disabilities.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas Disability Pride Month provides an opportunity to recommit to empowering people with disabilities, ensuring equal access to all spaces and opportunities in our community,

[Nicole Morell]: and recentering on areas in the city where we must improve accessibility in order to be a truly inclusive and equitable city.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it therefore resolved that the Medford City Council recognize and celebrates July as Disability Pride Month.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, so to understand,

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, that's the only question I have at this time.

[Nicole Morell]: I did just want to know,

[Nicole Morell]: Myself, I know there's many people in the city that partake, since doing compost, diapers aside, since doing compost, I mean, we barely have a bag of trash a week, and we know those bins can contain two, three bags of trash.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's been a huge noticeable difference for us.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think it would be exciting, particularly in these very hot days, to have the compost picked up weekly.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's just a personal note there.

[Nicole Morell]: Jumping on what Vice President Bears said, I think

[Nicole Morell]: I work at MIT in my day job, and they just released a series of impact goals to help them reach their climate goals.

[Nicole Morell]: And one is around waste, and it really focuses on food waste, because I think that's what a lot of people are coming up with, that when we do pound for pound, a lot of it is food.

[Nicole Morell]: And that's absolutely something we can put in a different stream that goes to biofuel, that goes to compost, that goes to something that's not rotting in a landfill with everything else, and just off-gassing in a way that's completely detrimental.

[Nicole Morell]: as we look towards our climate goals as a city, it can feel, I think to Vice President Bears's point, we can think about heat and flooding and all these things and see them, and those, absolutely, those feel like, those are climate change, those feel like climate change, but waste is such a big part of it, and it's something that we as individuals absolutely can do to make an impact when given the right tools to do so.

[Nicole Morell]: So I really appreciate that forward thinking with this and looking into that and understanding that

[Nicole Morell]: We will explore it as we get there.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: And I appreciate you bringing this forward and I agree with you that I wish it were a more infrastructure, a more permanent solution.

[Nicole Morell]: And what I'm gonna say next has nothing to do with your point, because I absolutely hear your point and I'm not disagreeing with you, but I just wanna say because

[Nicole Morell]: I'm not an expert on every intersection in this city.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm an expert on this intersection because I live about 300 yards from it and I walk it, I bike it, I drive it.

[Nicole Morell]: The only thing, I don't know, I don't know how to roller blade.

[Nicole Morell]: That's about the only thing I do not do through this intersection.

[Nicole Morell]: And I want to say that I am ecstatic.

[Nicole Morell]: I think it looked a little bit better.

[Nicole Morell]: That was, you know, there are spots in Winchester too, where the paint actually is smudged and doesn't look great either.

[Nicole Morell]: These things happen.

[Nicole Morell]: But every single, with the exception of the extremely long crosswalk about from the Whitmore Brook entrance towards the cemetery, every crosswalk in that intersection was a blind crosswalk.

[Nicole Morell]: You cross and you hoped someone saw you, whether they were coming off of Playstead, they couldn't see you cross Winthrop.

[Nicole Morell]: Whether you're crossing Playstead and they're coming off Winthrop, they couldn't see you.

[Nicole Morell]: Imagine having a stroller and pushing it in front of you and you hope to God someone sees you before they hit the stroller you're pushing for you.

[Nicole Morell]: I saw a woman a few weeks ago and the MBTA bus driver was actually extremely helpful in this situation.

[Nicole Morell]: He was wonderful.

[Nicole Morell]: And she was on the far side.

[Nicole Morell]: She was on the fell side and she was, she had like a walker, a roller, you know, walker with wheels and she was with her grandson.

[Nicole Morell]: She couldn't figure out which, which bus stop she needed to be at.

[Nicole Morell]: And she crossed over Winthrop street and then she crossed over place said twice because it's so wide right there.

[Nicole Morell]: And she got to the MBTA bus driver who told her actually you were in the right spot in the first place.

[Nicole Morell]: And I had entered the situation at that point and I had my elderly dog, would not walk any farther, so I couldn't help her.

[Nicole Morell]: So I sat there and I watched as she crossed the three streets again, and I held my breath.

[Nicole Morell]: I absolutely held my breath because I know how scary that intersection is.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just wanna know at what point we decided that that was acceptable, that for people to move as fast as they can, as they can in their cars is the more acceptable route.

[Nicole Morell]: than doing what we can to allow pedestrians to travel safely across streets.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's something that really frustrates me.

[Nicole Morell]: I've seen the discussion on Facebook that we are designing for a problem that doesn't exist.

[Nicole Morell]: Those people don't spend time in that.

[Nicole Morell]: I have seen countless people trying to cross that street.

[Nicole Morell]: Rarely someone will stop and let you cross the street.

[Nicole Morell]: Someone comes flying from Winchester and tries to go around them and tries to not intentionally, but almost nail someone in the crosswalk.

[Nicole Morell]: It's an incredibly dangerous intersection.

[Nicole Morell]: And since the interventions have been put in,

[Nicole Morell]: I've seen so many people in the area biking and walking, and it's not because they weren't there.

[Nicole Morell]: They have always been there, but they said, I'm not gonna cross that.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm not gonna walk that area.

[Nicole Morell]: That area is terrifying.

[Nicole Morell]: And now they're out and they're using it.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think it's wonderful to see.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm really happy.

[Nicole Morell]: The barriers are a little ugly.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, I will take ugly a million times over for safety improvements.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just wanna point out the fact that those very same barriers were begged for in front of some of the tonier streets in the city

[Nicole Morell]: prevent people from parking and accessing the lakes.

[Nicole Morell]: So those barriers exist in other places in the city that people seem to have no issue with because it prevents people from having access.

[Nicole Morell]: But when we add them to increase access, people get mad.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'll step off my soapbox.

[Nicole Morell]: But again, I probably walk through this intersection or bike through it or drive through it a half a dozen times each day.

[Nicole Morell]: And I want to be clear that I absolutely support

[Nicole Morell]: what has been done there, and I've heard from many people that support it, and I haven't heard from any people that probably don't even think to reach out, because they're biking and they're walking and they're enjoying it, and they're not thinking of emailing people about it.

[Nicole Morell]: So, I know we have a member of the public who would like to speak, so.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Castagnani, I see your hand up.

[Nicole Morell]: Or it might be still up, but I am assuming it's up again.

[Nicole Morell]: I will unmute you.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, we can hear you.
