[Nicole Morell]: 22-461 to Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding the Community Preservation Committee appropriation request.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear President Morell and members of the Medford City Council, on behalf of the Community Preservation Committee, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following recommendations of the Community Preservation Committee requesting the appropriation of $5,000 from the CPA General Reserve

[Nicole Morell]: to Medford School Department for a small grant to replace playground elements at the Roberts Elementary School, requesting the appropriation of $5,000 from the CPA General Reserve to Medford School Department for a small grant to replace playground elements at the Brooks Elementary School.

[Nicole Morell]: The project will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund by category, General Reserve.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Nicole Morell]: Respectfully submitted, Mayor Brianna Landau-Kern.

[Nicole Morell]: I do see we have- Move approval, Madam President.

[Nicole Morell]: Move approval.

[Nicole Morell]: Before I do see we have Daniel Evans or Roberta Cameron from the CDA if you'd like to speak if not.

[Nicole Morell]: So on the motion of Councilor Knight, as seconded by Councilor Caraviello, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-462 to the Honorable President and members of the Metro City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: Water meter replacement project funding recommendation.

[Nicole Morell]: As you may be aware, the current meter system the city uses to measure and record water use is nearing its end of life.

[Nicole Morell]: We plan to replace the existing water meters in the city with new meters that meet the current needs.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a three-year project with a cost of an estimate of $8,500,000.

[Nicole Morell]: The Department of Public Works, DPW, prepared the following information in support of funding the water meter replacement project.

[Nicole Morell]: This information summarizes and documents the plan to fund this project.

[Nicole Morell]: The DPW recommends that this be funded from two sources.

[Nicole Morell]: The first is the MWRA Tier 2 Local Water Assistance Program, LWSAP, and the second is ARPA.

[Nicole Morell]: The project is eligible for both sources and has been pre-coordinated with the MWRA program.

[Nicole Morell]: The MWRA program is typically used for water and sewer capital improvement projects and regulatory compliance programs.

[Nicole Morell]: However, these types of projects are eligible for other funding sources, including but not limited to ARPA and retained earnings.

[Nicole Morell]: The following is a recommendation funding breakdown.

[Nicole Morell]: The MWRA loan portion will require an approved loan order from the City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: The purpose of this memo is to inform you further about the project and begin the process to obtain support from City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: $7,800,000 borrowed from the MWRA Tier 2 LWSAP program.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a 0% loan paid back over 10 years and $700,000 paid from ARPA.

[Nicole Morell]: MWRA local water system assistance program assistance program information.

[Nicole Morell]: This program is a 0% interest loan program that has paid off over 10 years.

[Nicole Morell]: The city currently has phase two and phase three funding available.

[Nicole Morell]: Phase two will only be available through the end of 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: The tier two portion of this project is a restricted amount of funding within each phase that can be spent on certain types of projects such as meter replacements.

[Nicole Morell]: The breakdowns of each phase and available restricted tier two funds are below.

[Nicole Morell]: Phase two total available is $3,662,000.

[Nicole Morell]: Phase two tier two available is $2,518,006 of the total.

[Nicole Morell]: Phase three total available is $5,400,000.

[Nicole Morell]: Phase three tier three available is $5,370,526 of the total.

[Nicole Morell]: Total available for a tier two restricted amount is $7,888,532.

[Nicole Morell]: This recommendation includes using most of the phase two tier two available funds leaving $1,143,994 available for other eligible projects and using $5,281,994 from the phase three tier two available funds leaving $88,532 for other eligible projects.

[Nicole Morell]: There are other projects we would typically target MWRA, LWSAP for funding.

[Nicole Morell]: However, they are also eligible for other available sources.

[Nicole Morell]: Due to the smaller size of these projects, they're more appropriate for either ARPA retained earnings or remaining funds from MWRA, potentially other sources.

[Nicole Morell]: Water and Soil Superintendent Dan Stoneking and Head Meteor Technician Ron Baker will be available to answer questions on this important project.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

[Nicole Morell]: Respectfully submitted, Mayor Brianna Leno-Kirk.

[Nicole Morell]: President Paris.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you very much.

[Nicole Morell]: If I could also just get name and address for the record for both of you.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm just your like your Medford City Hall.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, great.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: President Bears and then back to Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: We can see around the country that the reproductive rights of everyone are under attack, have been rolled back have been removed for countless people.

[Nicole Morell]: I know many may say that this is not a city issue but it's been made clear that these rights are being attacked at every single level, and there is no stopping point.

[Nicole Morell]: These are rights that when removed will

[Nicole Morell]: or do endanger the health, endanger the lives, endanger the future of individuals who seek reproductive care at so many different levels, whether it's abortion, whether it's miscarriage management, whether it's IVF, expanding families, making decisions that are right for families.

[Nicole Morell]: These are decisions that, these rights being removed,

[Nicole Morell]: and every level also tend to impact the most marginalized in our society who need these services.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just wanna make sure that we open the discussion, that we talk about what we can do on a city level to make sure that these rights that are enshrined, remain enshrined, that they remain protected.

[Nicole Morell]: We as elected officials are stewards of the residents.

[Nicole Morell]: And I've heard from countless residents who say, what can we do on the city level?

[Nicole Morell]: What can the city council do?

[Nicole Morell]: People are scared, they should be scared.

[Nicole Morell]: And we need to do what we can to protect the reproductive health of residents.

[Nicole Morell]: Medford Mass 02155 for a special permit to amend its hours of operation in accordance with Medford Zoning Ordinance Chapter 94-7.2.1 to operate extended hours at its business at 177 College Ave, aka 161 College Ave, Medford Mass.

[Nicole Morell]: 02155 said site being located in a mixed use zoning district as follows.

[Nicole Morell]: Extended hours of operation requested, 5 a.m.

[Nicole Morell]: I wanna thank the council for their willingness to take part in what has been a very wild ride of a budget season as we navigated this strange place.

[Nicole Morell]: I think it is a testament to how far this body has come.

[Nicole Morell]: Two years ago, council budget talks came to a halt for a less than perfect situation.

[Nicole Morell]: And we had a less, less, less, less than perfect situation this year, and everyone still came to the table

[Nicole Morell]: for every meeting that they could, COVID and family and everything else barred.

[Nicole Morell]: So I just want to thank my fellow Councilors for navigating this process with me in good faith.

[Nicole Morell]: So on the motion of, no, no.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Vice President Bears, seconded by Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Correct.

[Nicole Morell]: Before we get to that, if I could.

[Nicole Morell]: to speak from the chair, I will be brief.

[Nicole Morell]: I know that sometimes folks, members of the public, presidents may say, we need to cut more from the budget.

[Nicole Morell]: Clearly there's some fat to cut.

[Nicole Morell]: And I really encourage you to attend our meetings, to look at the budget sheets.

[Nicole Morell]: We haven't been given them in a way that can be made readily available to the public when that is available.

[Nicole Morell]: I encourage you to look at the budget because what is offered to our departments is so, so bare bones.

[Nicole Morell]: There's really nowhere to cut.

[Nicole Morell]: We already aren't offering the services that people deserve.

[Nicole Morell]: There's nowhere to cut.

[Nicole Morell]: So I just encourage people to look at that.

[Nicole Morell]: And then also as Vice President Bears said, this is not a challenge that occurred overnight, but it's something that's come to roost.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think we've seen tonight more creativity around solutions offered by this council in this meeting, and even resulting from our previous work of how to raise revenue for this city than has been presented to us by the administration.

[Nicole Morell]: because level funding is not creative.

[Nicole Morell]: As we've seen tonight, as we saw in our Committee of the Whole, level funding does not provide level service, and level funding means vastly different things to different departments.

[Nicole Morell]: When we level fund a budget for a library as the same small space where it had services from that building and occupied, you're not gonna get the level of service that you deserve, that residents deserve.

[Nicole Morell]: And I wanna, I'll end with a quote that I've used in past years, and that a budget is a moral document.

[Nicole Morell]: We fund what we value.

[Nicole Morell]: And we have been shown by this administration, we'll just say two things, we haven't covered every budget.

[Nicole Morell]: We've been showed that the administration does not value the new library, and the administration does not value the work that this body does, and the work that is asked for by residents for us to do.

[Nicole Morell]: And just two budgets reflect that.

[Nicole Morell]: So thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: A lot of elderly people, a lot of people, you know that take the bus may not have access, you know, to a zoom meeting maybe at work during this time and so this is asking that the MBTA hold an in person meeting for those folks impacted in the inner core which is what includes Medford so the MBTA is hosting a number of in person meetings but the vast majority of them are in Boston.

[Nicole Morell]: and communities that aren't Medford and communities that aren't actually, I believe, in the inner core.

[Nicole Morell]: So they're leaving a lot of folks out from this decision making.

[Nicole Morell]: So also in lieu of a dedicated MBTA meeting, perhaps we can have a committee of the whole where we can have an MBTA representative attend before the comment period is closed.

[Nicole Morell]: So that would be something we'd be looking at for before or around our summer meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: That way residents can at least attend that in person.

[Nicole Morell]: So if you've already seen the plan and you have thoughts on it, please submit your comments.

[Nicole Morell]: This is not a done deal.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a lot of ideas.

[Nicole Morell]: And we want to get feedback from as many residents as possible and get feedback from those folks that are actually using these services who might not be able to attend that Zoom meeting for a variety of reasons.

[Nicole Morell]: So letting them know about the Zoom meeting if they can attend, working with the city clerk to see if we can get

[Nicole Morell]: the MBTA to host their own meeting, and then also working with the city clerk to see if we can get the MBTA, get an MBTA representative to attend a future Committee of the Whole so that we can solicit feedback from all of our residents that are gonna be impacted by this redesign.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion on the motion of Councilor Collins seconded by

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng, all those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-378 offered by Vice President Fares and Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it so resolved by the Medford City Council that the city clerk create an internal office process and a shared spreadsheet for tracking requests by the city council to the administration and or state agencies and their responses.

[Nicole Morell]: The spreadsheet would include the date, paper number, resolution language, requested deadline for response, if any, and link to a copy of the response if received.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it further resolved that the City Council meet in Committee of the Whole to discuss this process with the City Clerk and needed staff.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it further resolved that beginning in September 2022, the City Council will hold monthly Committee of the Whole meetings to review responses and outstanding requests.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Would that language around the reports too, would that be an amendment?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, vice and bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion on the emotion of counts for nights seconded by vice and bears.

[Nicole Morell]: All those in favor.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed, the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-379 offered by Councilor Tseng and Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that an ordinance be discussed in subcommittee, which would secure the rights of individuals seeking gender affirming care and forbid the city of Medford and municipal entities from assisting out of state requests for civil or criminal action against those who allow a person, whether child or adult to receive gender affirming care or those who seek gender affirming care themselves.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion from Councilors.

[Nicole Morell]: If I could briefly from the chair, I want to thank Councilor Tseng and Councilor Collins for bringing this forward and Councilor Tseng for making that amendment.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins, I think you really hit the nail on the head where to do nothing at this point would be regressive.

[Nicole Morell]: I understand that, you know, people may say, this is not a city level issue, why are you discussing this?

[Nicole Morell]: And I think we're seeing across the country, we're seeing multiple states turn to policy by way of bounty hunters to enact policy by putting bounties on those seeking reproductive care, seeking gender affirming care.

[Nicole Morell]: And I agree with Vice President Bears, if there is anything we can do at the city level,

[Nicole Morell]: we absolutely need to do it to protect our residents.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's what's right, it's what's just, and to do nothing would be regressive.

[Nicole Morell]: So I thank you for bringing this forward.

[Nicole Morell]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm just, I'm asking.

[Nicole Morell]: If you'd like the council to speak, they can respond.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng, Councilor Cohn's advice is embarrassing.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Announcements, accolades and remembrances 22-358 offered by Vice President Beyers.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council congratulate Building Commissioner Paul Moki on his retirement and 38 years of service to the city of Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpella.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Ike.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: And if I could, I mean, my fellow councilors have said so much, and I think just hearing people speak at length about Commissioner Moki just is a testament to who he is and the work he does.

[Nicole Morell]: when she helps us all I think one of my early wins as a Councilor in my first term was a resident had reached out about their neighbor had you know large shipping container a lot of open storage and something that was a violation of code and it was an issue they've been battling for so long and Mr. Moki was finally able to get you know get it taken care of getting it to the right person and you know the resident thanked me profusely but it's it's it's not a lot of times it's not us it's the people who work at City Hall it's people like Commissioner Moki who

[Nicole Morell]: go the extra mile they are they they're so responsive and just really get it done for the residents of our community and he's come to countless meetings as vice president bears said and you would never get a sense of you know how he feels about an issue personally he comes with his his work hat on and he says you know this is what we can do this is what we can't do and it's always been so welcome and I appreciate it so much.

[Nicole Morell]: And he will be absolutely sorely missed.

[Nicole Morell]: As I said, 30 years of institutional knowledge is really tough to top.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think, you know, he's working to the last minute.

[Nicole Morell]: I had sent him a paper before I knew he was retiring, our tree ordinance, to see if we could get some feedback.

[Nicole Morell]: And he said, sure, I'll get that to you right away.

[Nicole Morell]: When, you know, he's retiring in three days.

[Nicole Morell]: And I said, you know, we'll figure it out.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's, he'll absolutely be missed.

[Nicole Morell]: And I thank him for his many years of service to this community and to this body in particular as well.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Pricers and bearers, all those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: So 22360.

[Nicole Morell]: So what this paper is, it goes just into the efforts of corporations like Uber, Lyft, and DoorDash to keep their employees classified as independent contractors.

[Nicole Morell]: And as such, these employees do not get benefits or pay into things like social security.

[Nicole Morell]: A lot of times they are not getting a living wage once, or even a minimum wage once the hours and their shifts are calculated

[Nicole Morell]: These companies contend that these folks are independent contractors and not employees, despite the fact that they are required to perform a set number of shifts.

[Nicole Morell]: They do have flexibility in scheduling.

[Nicole Morell]: They are not allowed to refuse a certain number of rides or they won't be able to be on the app anymore.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is in response to House Bill 1234, that would continue to exempt these gay economy businesses from paying into Social Security unemployment, which costs Massachusetts taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars, and we can use these programs for everyone.

[Nicole Morell]: And it would affirm our support in joining Councilors across the greater Boston region, workers, consumers, community members, faith organizations, environmental and racial justice advocates, labor rights, civil rights, and union organizers to urge Massachusetts legislature to oppose House Bill 1234,

[Nicole Morell]: and the proposed 2022 state ballot initiative with similar language.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is just really something to affirm our support.

[Nicole Morell]: I understand Councilors, you know, certain times don't like to go on issues that go up to the state level in this way, but I would just argue that this is something that very much impacts our community.

[Nicole Morell]: These are people who live in our community.

[Nicole Morell]: These are workers that are

[Nicole Morell]: As I said, oftentimes not making a living wage they're not making a minimum wage.

[Nicole Morell]: And these are services that use our roads our streets.

[Nicole Morell]: And we talked about the congestion and the dangerousness that happens because of all these services, and they're essentially.

[Nicole Morell]: they're allowed to do whatever they want.

[Nicole Morell]: They say these people aren't employees, we're not going to give them benefits, we're not going to make sure they have a living wage, and they want to codify that.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is just asking the council to join with other councils and leaders in the area to stand up and say that these workers deserve the same rights as all other employees, because that's what they are.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears, Councilor Caraviello, Collin Sands, go around.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears first.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Zoom would like to speak on the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: All those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: Aye.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-361 offered by Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the Metro City Council have a representative from Eversource attend the next city council meeting to give the council an update on an ongoing project on Mystic Avenue and Winthrop Street via further resolve at the city engineer and dpw also be in attendance.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Further discussion.

[Nicole Morell]: I have asked the city engineer if they have any updates on timing.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's obviously nuts on them and resources and give them information.

[Nicole Morell]: I've asked them, you know, month, two months ago, because we're in high construction season, and nothing's happening.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-362 offered by Councilor Tseng, whereas the US Supreme Court's decision in Shurtleff versus City of Boston creates important implications for municipalities and public entities with regards to flag raising practices and policies, and whereas the city of Medford has been advised to examine existing practices and policies regarding flag raising to ensure compliance with the First Amendment,

[Nicole Morell]: and to also consider examining their formal or informal policies and practices regarding display of banners, flags, message boards, and other signage on and use of public buildings and property.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the city administration provide a report to the city council on its current practices and policies regarding flag raising and other displays, which may be affected by the short-lived decision, especially with further regard to requests from private or non-governmental groups slash individuals.

[Nicole Morell]: And be it further resolved that the city administration

[Nicole Morell]: Is there any discussion from the council?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Knights.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: So we have a motion from Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: I do want to note that the newly adopted rules state that following a public hearing, a six calendar day public comment period shall commence.

[Nicole Morell]: Public comments shall be submitted writing to the city clerk.

[Nicole Morell]: The council shall neither approve nor deny any matter requiring public hearing until the conclusion of the public comment period, unless waived by a majority vote of the council.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Councilor Knight to waive the six day waiting requirement, seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: So that would be the motion to waive and approve.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, seven in favor, zero in the negative.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes and the extended hours are approved.

[Nicole Morell]: Congratulations.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-350 offered by Councilor Tseng, whereas the 2022 spring edition of the Harvard youth poll found that nearly half, 45% of LGBTQ youth feel under attack a lot because of their sexual orientation.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas approximately three fifths, 59% of young black Americans, 43% of AAPI youth and 37% of Hispanics believe people of their racial background are under a lot of attack in America.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas a majority of young Americans between the ages of 18 and 29 52% report feelings of depression or hopelessness and 24% report thoughts of self harm, a feeling particularly prevalent in young Americans who are black 35% API 33% female 26% LGBTQ 39%, and in a bad financial position 35%.

[Nicole Morell]: And whereas the Surgeon General has issued an advisory which calls for a swift and coordinated response to this mental health crisis as the nation continues to battle the COVID-19 pandemic, be it resolved that the City Council ask the City Administration and School Department to study youth mental health in Medford and to prepare an action plan to address the mental health epidemic, both for children within the Medford public school system and youth living in Medford more generally.

[Nicole Morell]: and be it also resolved that the Subcommittee on Public Health and Community Safety invite relevant city officials, experts on youth mental health and Medford's youth leaders to discuss steps the city can take to address challenges to our youth population and mental health.

[Nicole Morell]: along and across the following public way or ways here and after name said poles, wires, or fixtures to be located substantially in accordance with the plan number 30453109 marked Winthrop Street, Medford, Massachusetts, dated November 23rd, 2021, and received and filed in the office of the city clerk on December 21st, 2021.

[Nicole Morell]: Wherefore it prays that after due notice and hearing as provided by law,

[Nicole Morell]: It be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures, as it may find necessary said polls to be erected substantially in accordance with the plan number 30453109 Mark Winthrop Street, Medford, Massachusetts and available for inspection in the office of city clerk Medford City Hall room 10385 George Peabody Passage Drive.

[Nicole Morell]: Medford Massachusetts, also for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals cables and wires in the above or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles and buildings as each upset petitioners may desire for distributing purposes.

[Nicole Morell]: Petitioner agrees to reserve space for one cross arm at a suitable point on each of said poles for the fire police telephone and telegraph signal wires belonging to the municipality and used by it exclusively for municipal purposes.

[Nicole Morell]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[Nicole Morell]: Plan number 30453109 Winthrop Street National Grid to relocate one J.O.

[Nicole Morell]: pole on Winthrop Street beginning at a point approximately 20 feet northeast of the center line of the intersection of Winthrop Street and Lorain Road.

[Nicole Morell]: and continuing approximately 15 feet in northwest direction.

[Nicole Morell]: Relocate one pole P279 approximately 15 feet northwest from existing location to accommodate new driveway 2541 Winthrop Street.

[Nicole Morell]: Location approximately as shown on plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Nicole Morell]: The engineering division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Nicole Morell]: The grant of location is limited to the relocation of one joint owned pole

[Nicole Morell]: at the underground services associated with the full relocation.

[Nicole Morell]: Two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify dig safe and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Nicole Morell]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Nicole Morell]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appurtenances are adversely impacted.

[Nicole Morell]: The proponent shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines

[Nicole Morell]: remark prior to any excavation number for the final poll location shall be coordinated with Mary Kenny with the Mary Kenny way development so it will not adverse the impact traffic sight lines number five the sidewalk restoration shall be done in coordination with the Mary Kenny way subdivision project

[Nicole Morell]: and per the requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[Nicole Morell]: At a minimum, the restoration shall include new concrete sidewalk panels replaced in kind with an expansion joint placed around the pole.

[Nicole Morell]: The project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris from the duration of the installation.

[Nicole Morell]: Approved, Superintendent of Wires.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Motions, orders and resolutions 22-012.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the rules of the Medford City Council be updated to replace rule two meetings with the following.

[Nicole Morell]: Rule two meetings.

[Nicole Morell]: Regular meetings of the city council shall be held every two weeks on Tuesday evening at 7 p.m.

[Nicole Morell]: beginning on the first Tuesday in January.

[Nicole Morell]: Meetings shall be held in the council chambers.

[Nicole Morell]: Meetings of the committee of the whole shall be scheduled by the president.

[Nicole Morell]: Meetings of subcommittee shall be scheduled by the subcommittee chairperson.

[Nicole Morell]: Scheduling preference for meetings of committees and subcommittees shall be on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings beginning at 6pm.

[Nicole Morell]: Except in an emergency, no meeting of the City Council shall be held unless a notice of such has been filed at least 48 hours prior to such meeting with the City Clerk, as required by the Massachusetts Open Meeting Law.

[Nicole Morell]: Upon receipt of such notice by the City Clerk, they shall immediately cause the same or copy thereof to be posted publicly in their office.

[Nicole Morell]: For the purpose of this section, emergency shall mean a situation where immediate undelayed action is deemed to be imperative.

[Nicole Morell]: Unless city council shall vote to go into executive session, all meetings of the city council and committees and subcommittees thereof shall be open to the public and to the press and the city council shall provide that residents and employees of the city shall have reasonable opportunity to be heard at any such meeting as outlined in rule 16, rule 19 and rule 22.

[Nicole Morell]: All meetings of the City Council shall include an option for virtual participation through a video conferencing platform.

[Nicole Morell]: Members, residents, petitioners, and interested parties shall be provided with the necessary information to access this platform and participate virtually.

[Nicole Morell]: However, members shall make every reasonable attempt to attend meetings in person.

[Nicole Morell]: materials provided to the members of the city council shall be posted on the city website at the same time as meeting agendas, except those materials deemed private or otherwise requiring review by the city solicitor.

[Nicole Morell]: The city council shall maintain accurate records of their meeting setting forth the action taken at each meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: A summary of all matters voted shall be made available with reasonable promptness after each meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: The records of each meeting shall become a public record and be available to the public upon being approved.

[Nicole Morell]: The City Council may at any meeting by a majority vote discontinue any further meetings herein before schedule.

[Nicole Morell]: via further resolve that these updates becomes effective on September 1st, 2022.

[Nicole Morell]: I just wanna note before the discussion that the council has met a number of committees of the whole, as well as the rules and ordinances subcommittee met on these proposed changes a number of times.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Councilor Collins to approve, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Caraviellol.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion?

[Nicole Morell]: Come to Scar Valley.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion from the council?

[Nicole Morell]: Just as a member of the council I'm just going to speak from the chair as I've been relatively quiet on this just trying to manage debate but I, I support this because I do believe this reflects this the format of how work gets done in this council as Councilor Knight has spoken.

[Nicole Morell]: I understand the concerns of my fellow Councilors they're absolutely heated they're heard.

[Nicole Morell]: You know, to counter Carlos point I understand along meetings but you know right now sometimes we'll have a meeting that starts at five we start with the committee the whole, and then we keep going so we're in meetings four or five hours even if we're not going late you've been meeting for a long time so allowing for, you know, more freedom with those meetings to to get the work done and not have things kind of running into each other as we did, did tonight and I think also.

[Nicole Morell]: The Committee of the whole the subcommittee structure does allow for for more voices to be heard for different voices because there are a lot of folks that are focused on a single issue.

[Nicole Morell]: And they might not come to a council meeting, they might not have the time for that, but they're at that subcommittee they're at that committee the whole you can look back on recent meetings on different topics and

[Nicole Morell]: there's a lot of dialogue and there's a lot of folks that you might not see in a regular meeting, but will come out to that meeting and they will speak about their single issue, whether it's curb appeal or relief blowers or food trucks.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is why it has my support.

[Nicole Morell]: I absolutely do believe that this will facilitate the council to do the work that it does best and that it's statutory work.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's ordinances, it's policy, it's reviewing the budget, which we do in communities as a whole.

[Nicole Morell]: and just getting that work done.

[Nicole Morell]: So this has my support and I just wanted to say that just to go on record and share that as I have been fairly quiet, just managing to be.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion from my fellow councilors?

[Nicole Morell]: On to legal notice to the Medford Community Development Block Grant Program, Program Year 48 Annual Action Plan public hearing.

[Nicole Morell]: A public hearing will be held by the Medford City Council on Tuesday, May 3, 2022.

[Nicole Morell]: Details will be posted by the City Clerk's Office prior to the hearing.

[Nicole Morell]: The purpose of this public hearing will be to invite the general public and representatives of public service agencies to express comments regarding the City's Community Development Block Grant Annual Action Plan for Community Development and Planning.

[Nicole Morell]: The action plan contains the proposed use of Community Development Block Grant funds for the program year which extends from July 1 2022 through June 30 of 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: The Office of Planning, Development, Sustainability will be requesting that the Medford City Council authorize Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, official representative of the City of Medford, to submit the annual action plan

[Nicole Morell]: application for funds and all other assurances and certifications to the US Department of Housing and Urban Development.

[Nicole Morell]: The city is applying for an estimated $1,546,988 in block grant funds.

[Nicole Morell]: Funds are estimated and details on the increasing or decreasing of proposed activities and budget can be found within the draft plan.

[Nicole Morell]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations, slash aids, TDD 781-393-2516.

[Nicole Morell]: Signed, Adam Herdevis, City Clerk.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: At this time, Director Hunt, if you would like to give us a summary presentation.

[Nicole Morell]: As Vice President Bears mentioned, this was discussed at length in a previous committee as a whole as well.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Director Hunt and Administrator Williams.

[Nicole Morell]: As this is a public hearing, we'll open the public hearing now.

[Nicole Morell]: And anyone driving through, I don't know how you would think to come back to Medford Square in a day or another night because it was an absolute disaster.

[Nicole Morell]: Absolutely.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-338 April 20, 2022 to the honorable president members of Medford city council regarding the retiree cost of living adjustment increase your president Morell and members of the city council on March 31st, 2022, the Medford retirement board voted with the unanimous vote of five to zero in favor of informing the city council

[Nicole Morell]: of the board's intention of increasing the maximum amount of earnings subject to the COLA cost of living adjustment from $16,000 to $18,000 effective July 1, 2022, subject to the approval of the City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: Increasing the maximum amount of earnings subject to COLA from $16,000 to $18,000 will increase the maximum COLA per eligible retiree from $480 a year, $40 a month,

[Nicole Morell]: to $540 a year.

[Nicole Morell]: Currently, there are 618 retirees and 450 have a retirement allowance greater than $18,000.

[Nicole Morell]: The remaining 160 retirees have an annual retirement allowance below $18,000 and will not be affected by the increase.

[Nicole Morell]: In aggregate, the COLA cost will increase approximately $2,250 a month

[Nicole Morell]: 27,000 a year.

[Nicole Morell]: The cost associated with the increase will be funded from the pension fund and will not affect the city's fiscal year 2023 budget.

[Nicole Morell]: The cost of the city will be included in the next actuarial evaluation currently scheduled for January 1st, 2024.

[Nicole Morell]: If you have any questions, Chairman Rick Jordan and I will be in attendance for the April 26th meeting.

[Nicole Morell]: Sincerely, Mark Minervini, Executive Director.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight.

[Nicole Morell]: Any discussion from the Council?

[Nicole Morell]: 22-324 to Honorable President Morell, Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear President Morell and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the Massachusetts School Building Authority, MSBA statement of interest on behalf of Medford High School that has been prepared by the Medford Public Schools for consideration for the MSBA's core program.

[Nicole Morell]: The submission is in follow-up to the March 31st letter you received from the superintendent of schools.

[Nicole Morell]: Superintendent Maurice-Edouard-Vincent and Assistant Superintendent David Murphy will be on hand at your meeting should there be any questions or additional information that members would like to obtain.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Nicole Morell]: MSBA required form of vote to submit statement of interest.

[Nicole Morell]: Resolved.

[Nicole Morell]: Having convened in an open meeting on April 19th, 2022 prior to the SOI submission closing date, the City Council of the City of Medford in accordance with its charter bylaws and ordinances

[Nicole Morell]: has voted to authorize Superintendent Maurice Edouard Vincent to submit to the Massachusetts School Building Authority.

[Nicole Morell]: The statement of interest formed dated April 2022 for Medford High School located at 49 Winthrop Street, which describes and explains the following deficiencies and the priority categories for which an application may be submitted to the Massachusetts School Building Authority in the future.

[Nicole Morell]: The Medford City Council hereby further specifically acknowledges that by submitting the statement of interest form, the Massachusetts School Building Authority in no way guarantees the acceptance or the approval of an application, the awarding of a grant, or any other funding commitments from the Massachusetts School Building Authority, or commits the city of Medford to filing an application for funding with the Massachusetts School Building Authority.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Motion to waive the reading in lieu of a summary.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Councilor Collins to waive the reading for overview from the superintendent.

[Nicole Morell]: Seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: All those in favor?

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed?

[Nicole Morell]: Motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Superintendent, if you'd like to give us an overview about what's being requested and what we'll be voting on tonight.

[Nicole Morell]: Statutory, unless you want to read what those two priorities are just for folks who might not have.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you very much.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Dr. Edward-Vincent.

[Nicole Morell]: Any, all right, Councilor Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion of Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Are there any further discussion from Councilors or would any members of the public like to speak?

[Nicole Morell]: Absolutely.

[Nicole Morell]: Just, I do have one letter to read into the record.

[Nicole Morell]: I don't see anyone who wants to speak in person, seeing on Zoom.

[Nicole Morell]: I do just have one letter from a resident to read into the record.

[Nicole Morell]: This is from Luke Prisner at 144th Street.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear city councilors, I address you this evening to ask for unanimous support for Medford High School's application to the state's School Building Assistant Program via Statement of Interest, SOI.

[Nicole Morell]: Today's vote is about SOI priorities and community unity.

[Nicole Morell]: It should not be confused with other subjects such as tax levies or project specifics, neither of those is in play as a result of this vote.

[Nicole Morell]: Instead, the district working on behalf of thousands of Medford parents and residents ask each of you to endorse the priorities they've selected to highlight before the MSBA Board of Directors.

[Nicole Morell]: Medford's application will be one among probably 100 such applications to the MSBA this year, out of which only about a 10th are selected into the MSBA program.

[Nicole Morell]: Therefore, it's very important to show the MSBA that we in Medford are all united in this cause.

[Nicole Morell]: The high school is now over 50 years old and fixing all of its problems on our own falls far beyond the current needs.

[Nicole Morell]: We need MSBA's help.

[Nicole Morell]: MSBA can only help school districts that compellingly state the case for need and urgency and are admitted into the MSBA program.

[Nicole Morell]: Selection is a game changer and may put Medford on a structured path in a several years long process to resolve our high school's woes, perhaps even in time for the graduating class of 2029.

[Nicole Morell]: The current SOI is Medford's third in the past five years.

[Nicole Morell]: It is normal and common for a district to apply multiple times, making refinements along the way.

[Nicole Morell]: In 2018 the City Council endorsed the district's SOI priorities, but unfortunately the MSBA did not select Medford that year.

[Nicole Morell]: Then again in 2019 this process repeated the City Council support for SOI priorities, but the outcome was the same.

[Nicole Morell]: In between then and now the COVID-19 pandemic began disrupting normal activities starting in 2020.

[Nicole Morell]: Now in 2022, normal activities are resuming and the acuity of Medford High's need and urgency has grown.

[Nicole Morell]: As a community, we must act together and act quickly to re-engage on the SOI process.

[Nicole Morell]: It's the first step.

[Nicole Morell]: No money is committed and no decisions are made apart from the decision to ask the MSBA for support.

[Nicole Morell]: That is the real purpose of today's vote.

[Nicole Morell]: Namely, do each of you agree that Medford High School needs either rehabilitation or renovation?

[Nicole Morell]: If you do, then please vote yay.

[Nicole Morell]: Many residents I've spoken with believe it is time, and we all hope you agree.

[Nicole Morell]: Medford High School's condition has not improved over time.

[Nicole Morell]: In many ways, the burdens on its old bones have increased, and the urgency with which we must act has never been greater.

[Nicole Morell]: I thank you for your thoughtful consideration on this matter.

[Nicole Morell]: Please unanimously endorse the district's SOI priorities today.

[Nicole Morell]: Best regards, Luke.

[Nicole Morell]: Anyone else like to speak on the motion of Councilor Caraviello second by second bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the role.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Six in the affirmative one absent the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: And thank you, Dr. Gordon said and assistant superintendent on the motion, Vice President bear second second by Councilor Kelly all those in favor.

[Nicole Morell]: All those opposed.

[Nicole Morell]: The motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-323 to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council regarding the Board of Election Commission appointment.

[Nicole Morell]: I am pleased to appoint you to a term to the Medford Board of Election Commissioners, which expires on March 30th, 2026.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Vice President Bears to approve the appointment of Mr. Crowley, seconded by Councilor Scharpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: 20-573 offered by Vice President Fares, be it so ordained by the Medford City Council that the revised ordinances of the city of Medford as most recently amended is hereby further amended by changing the language of chapter 74, quote, streets, sidewalks and other public places, article three, sidewalks, section 74-114 entitled removal of snow and ice.

[Nicole Morell]: Said section presently states, section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[Nicole Morell]: Whenever the sidewalk or any part of a sidewalk adjoining any building or lot of land on any street is encumbered with ice or snow, it shall be the duty of the tenant or occupant, and in case there should be no tenant or occupant of the whole of such building or lot of land, it shall be the duty of the owner or of the person having care of the sidewalk to cause such sidewalk to be made safe and convenient for public use.

[Nicole Morell]: or travel by removing the ice or snow or by covering the area with sand or some other suitable substance.

[Nicole Morell]: In case such tenant, occupant, owner, or other shall neglect to do so for the space of six hours during the daytime, he shall forfeit and pay the sum of $25 for the first offense and 50 for each successive day that the sidewalk shall continue to be encumbered.

[Nicole Morell]: Any person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: The fine for violation of this section shall be for the first offense $50 and for the second offense and subsequent offenses $100.

[Nicole Morell]: The language of said section 74 dash 114 shall hereby be amended to read as follows.

[Nicole Morell]: Section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[Nicole Morell]: A, removal of snow and ice from sidewalks.

[Nicole Morell]: Whenever snow or ice accumulates on a sidewalk, the owner, tenant, occupant, or agent thereof, any land or building abutting a sidewalk or walking path shall remove the snow and ice to provide a minimum passage of 36 inches for pedestrians on the sidewalk abutting the owner's property and the entrance to a pedestrian crossing abutting the sidewalk.

[Nicole Morell]: The owner, tenant, occupant, or agent thereof shall also remove snow within 36 inches of a fire hydrant within or abutting a sidewalk that abuts the owner's property sufficient to allow access to the hydrant.

[Nicole Morell]: The owner, tenant, occupant, or agent therefore shall remove the snow or ice or treat the sidewalk with calcium chloride pellets or other suitable and preferably environmentally friendly material to permit safe passage to pedestrians.

[Nicole Morell]: The owner tenant occupant or agent thereof shall not be responsible for moving snow on an abutting sidewalk if an excessive amount of snow is plowed onto the sidewalk by private municipal or state vehicles in the course of applying a public way, which cannot be reasonably removed as determined at this discretion of the code enforcement officer.

[Nicole Morell]: The owner, tenant, occupant, or agent thereof shall remove snow and ice within six daily hours after the snow stops falling or a snow emergency has been lifted, whichever is later, and the city may extend the deadline set forth in its discretion.

[Nicole Morell]: B, throwing or putting snow and ice into the street, a person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: C, enforcement.

[Nicole Morell]: The city's code enforcement officer or his designee shall enforce the ordinance in a manner provided in sections 1-13 of the ordinances and Massachusetts general law of chapter 40, section 21D.

[Nicole Morell]: If non-criminal disposition is elected, then any property owner who violates any provision of this bylaw shall be subject to the following penalties.

[Nicole Morell]: First offense, $50, second offense, $100, third and subsequent offense, 200, and the cost of removal of snow and ice as determined by the commissioner of public works.

[Nicole Morell]: Upon third violation during the term of ownership of the property of the duty imposed by the provision of this section, such duty may be performed by the Department of Public Works at the expense of the person liable to perform the same and the city may place a lien against the property for expenses incurred.

[Nicole Morell]: The city treasurer with approval of the mayor may in civil actions prosecute and adjust claims inuring to the city under the provisions of this section.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Would you like to add that as a B paper?

[Nicole Morell]: versus embarrassed.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion from the council?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tsengh.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-317, to President Nicole Morell and honorable members of the Medford City Council, from Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, regarding loan order sidewalk bonds.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear Madam President and City Councilors, I respect the request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order.

[Nicole Morell]: City of Medford loan or sidewalk bonds be it ordered that the sum of $1 million be and hereby is appropriated to pay the cost of constructing and reconstruction sidewalks throughout the city, including all costs incidental and related there to that to meet this appropriation a city treasurer with approval of the mayor.

[Nicole Morell]: is authorized to borrow said sum under and pursuant to Massachusetts general laws chapter 44 section 7 1 as amended and supplemented or pursuant to any other enabling authority and to issue bonds or notes of the city therefore and further ordered that the city treasurer is authorized to file an application with the appropriate officials of the commonwealth of massachusetts here and after the commonwealth

[Nicole Morell]: to qualify under chapter 44a of the general laws any and all bonds or notes of the city authorized by the vote or pursuant to any prior vote of the city and in such connection therewith to provide such information to execute documents as such officials of the commonwealth may require very truly yours mayor brianna um and then this is the same paper number okay continuing

[Nicole Morell]: I'm too present a formula members of the honorable member of city council regarding paper 22-317 on order opinion sidewalk box.

[Nicole Morell]: Dear Madam President and members of the Medford City Council, in accordance with the provisions of the Medford City Council Rule 22, I have examined the above captioned loan order as to its legality and hereby submit my findings.

[Nicole Morell]: I certify that the loan order set forth in Council Paper 22-317 in which authorization is sought to borrow $1 million for the purpose of paying the cost of constructing and reconstructing

[Nicole Morell]: various sidewalks throughout the city, including all costs incidental and related to their to and to issue bonds or notes of the city instead aggregate principal amount under and pursuant to general laws chapter 44 section seven, one, including the payment of all costs incidental and related there to it's valid.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm of the opinion that there is a lawful authority for the issuance of set bonds under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts presently in force.

[Nicole Morell]: I further certify that the purposes for which these bonds are to be issued, i.e., to pay for the cost of constructing and reconstructing sidewalks throughout the city and to issue bonds or notes of the city in said aggregate principal amount of $1 million, under and pursuant to General Laws Chapter 44, Section 7, including the payment of all costs incidental and related thereto.

[Nicole Morell]: is valid under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts presently enforced.

[Nicole Morell]: Respectfully, Kimberly M. Scanlon.

[Nicole Morell]: There are two footnotes regarding Rule 22.

[Nicole Morell]: The current rule ordinances and bond orders refer to the city solicitor.

[Nicole Morell]: Every ordinance and every order for bond issue shall, before its passage, be referred to the city solicitor, who shall forthwith examine the same as to its legality and notify the council in writing of his or her findings.

[Nicole Morell]: And the second footnote around general laws chapter 44 section 71 authorizes cities to borrow for landscaping, alteration, remediation, rehabilitation, or improvement of public land, the construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, improvement, alteration, remodeling, enlargement, demolition, removal or repair of public buildings, facilities, assets, works or infrastructure for a period not to exceed 30 years.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-318 to President Nicole Morell and honorable members of the Medford City Council for Mayor Brianna Longo-Hurton.

[Nicole Morell]: Regarding loan order stump removal bonds, dear Madam President and city councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order, City of Medford loan order stump removal bonds.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it ordered that the sum of $250,000 be and hereby is appropriate for the purpose of removing stumps for the improvement of public lanes throughout the city, including all costs incidental and related there to,

[Nicole Morell]: that to meet this appropriation, a city treasurer with approval of the mayor is authorized to borrow said sum under and pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 44, Section 7.1, as amended and supplemented, or pursuant to any other enabling authority, and to issue bonds or notes of the city, therefore.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm further ordered that the city treasurer is authorized to file an application with the appropriate officials of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts here and after the Commonwealth

[Nicole Morell]: qualify under Chapter 44 a of general laws, any and all bonds or notes of the city authorized by the vote or pursuant to any prior vote of the city, and in connection there with to provide such information execute such documents as such officials of the Commonwealth may require very truly yours, Mayor Brianna.

[Nicole Morell]: I certify that the loan order set forth in Council Paper 22-318, in which authorization is sought to borrow $250,000 for the purpose of removing stumps for the improvement of public land throughout the city, including all costs and incidental unrelated thereto, and to issue bonds or notes of the city in said aggregate principal amount under and pursuant to general laws, Chapter 44, Section 7,

[Nicole Morell]: One, including the payment of all costs incidental and related there to is valid.

[Nicole Morell]: I am of the opinion that there is lawful authority for the issuance of bonds under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts presently in force.

[Nicole Morell]: I further certify that the purposes for which these bonds are to be issued ie to remove stumps for the improvement of public lands throughout the city and to issue bonds for notice of the city.

[Nicole Morell]: In said aggregate principal amount of $250,000 under and pursuant to General Laws, Chapter 44, Section 7.1, including the payment of all costs incidental and related thereto, is valid under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts presently in force.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Four in the affirmative, two in the negative, one absent, the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-073 offered by President Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm gonna read through this.

[Nicole Morell]: We'll take Councilor Knight's motion first.

[Nicole Morell]: On the motion of Councilor Knight to waive the reading in favor of a brief synopsis from the President, seconded by Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, six in front of one absent the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is an ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: The idea behind the ordinance was originally presented to the council in February of 2020 by some CCSR students who had grave concerns about the impact of polystyrene, both as it's listed here on harm to aquatic life, pollution of waterways, human health risks from the leaching of chemicals when hot foods are placed in these items, as well as when these

[Nicole Morell]: items end up in waterways and then limited recycling options for these types of containers.

[Nicole Morell]: This would apply to prepared food, so it would apply to restaurants, it would apply to schools, it would apply to larger grocery stores that offer prepared foods.

[Nicole Morell]: There is a number of, the ban would be, if voted in favor, the ban would

[Nicole Morell]: be enforced by the health department upon their yearly inspection.

[Nicole Morell]: And if it passed, it would be implemented.

[Nicole Morell]: I wanna find the exact language for this.

[Nicole Morell]: It would be the ordinance to become effective on July 1st, 2023, or a date that is 180 days from the date that the mayor approves this ordinance or otherwise becomes effective, whichever is later.

[Nicole Morell]: There is also the opportunity for businesses to defer

[Nicole Morell]: for up to a year period, citing undue hardship.

[Nicole Morell]: And there is a number of reasons what undue hardship means.

[Nicole Morell]: So that would be circumstances or situations unique to a particular retail establishment, such as there is no reasonable alternatives to disposable food containers that are not made of polystyrene.

[Nicole Morell]: Circumstances or situations unique to the retail establishment such that compliance with requirements of this chapter would deprive a person of a legally protected right or circumstances where a retail establishment requires additional time in order to draw down the existing inventory of disposable food containers made of polystyrene.

[Nicole Morell]: I believe that covers the main points.

[Nicole Morell]: If there's any discussion, or it seems like I may have missed something.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bales.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes, deferments can be applied for beyond one year, and then also just going to the penalties and fines for violation.

[Nicole Morell]: The ordinance shall be enforced by the health department or its designees.

[Nicole Morell]: Whoever violates any provision of this ordinance may be penalized by a non-criminal disposition process as

[Nicole Morell]: provided in general laws chapter 40 section 21 D. If non criminal disposition is elected than any person who violates any provision of this bylaw shall be subject to the following penalties.

[Nicole Morell]: First offense a written warning.

[Nicole Morell]: Second offense $100 third offense $200 and the fourth and subsequent offense $300.

[Nicole Morell]: Is there any discussion?

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Powell.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: The prepared food definition, that is the intention as outlined.

[Nicole Morell]: the, it was concerned about the prepared food that in the committee of the whole, the discussion was that it would be food that was prepared for immediate consumption.

[Nicole Morell]: So the thought that the two large employers would not be impacted because they do not prepare food for immediate consumption.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion?

[Nicole Morell]: The motion of Vice President Bears to be ordained is the correct language for first reading.

[Nicole Morell]: Seconded by Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-304, be it resolved that the Metro City Council requests an update from the city administration on the solid waste task force, including the scope and goals of the task force, opportunities for short and long-term waste reduction, inefficacy evaluation of our current recycling services, opportunities to further reduce waste and more efficiently recycle in our next waste management contract, and how our city's progress towards a zero waste future can be publicly tracked and made available to the public.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is from Alicia Hunt, who is the Director of Planning, Development, and Sustainability.

[Nicole Morell]: And some of this is coming verbatim from the person who purchased the property.

[Nicole Morell]: So if this is incorrect, I apologize.

[Nicole Morell]: This is just the story that they are getting.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's a 34-unit building.

[Nicole Morell]: So the director of planning development sustainability and the housing planner spoke with the owner and some of his representatives this past Friday.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's a 34 unit building and the owner let them know that 18 units for tenants at will, 14 have leases until the fall.

[Nicole Morell]: The new owner purchased the building one year ago in March 2021, and he said that all units that are tenants at will were in that status when he purchased the building.

[Nicole Morell]: It's clear that his plan is to renovate kitchens, bathrooms, and redo floors, and that the tenants must vacate the apartments for this to occur as they are one-bathroom units.

[Nicole Morell]: It was clear that rent would go up after the renovations.

[Nicole Morell]: He agreed to extend the notice for the tenants at will an additional 30 days for those who needed an extension.

[Nicole Morell]: His representative, Jay Walsh, contacted the department on Friday night to let them know that everyone who had received a notice to quit had been notified that they could have an additional 30 days.

[Nicole Morell]: The director with the city requested that the owner give the tenants with leases as much notice as possible as it's necessary to look for now.

[Nicole Morell]: New rental units in September, given this market, look sorry, look now for rental units in September, given the market.

[Nicole Morell]: The owner indicated that he understood and would take into advisement and give more notice that he had been planning.

[Nicole Morell]: The city director requested that he give the tenants the opportunity to stay in the building, potentially by giving them the option to return to the renovated apartment.

[Nicole Morell]: This seems to be a new idea to him, but he seemed to think it was very reasonable and suggested that once some apartments were renovated, those with longer leases could be offered the option to lease one of the renovated apartments rather than being required to move out.

[Nicole Morell]: we emphasize, the city emphasized that we very much would like to retain Medford residents in Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: And I will make sure you guys get this.

[Nicole Morell]: There's just like two more paragraphs.

[Nicole Morell]: The city also presented him with information from the Medford Housing Authority on their opportunity for landlords to receive $1,000 for leasing a unit to a section eight voucher holder that hadn't previously leased to someone with section eight and let them know that the maximum section eight rents are what the maximum section eight rents are in Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: It's the city director's hope that he would consider Section 8 voucher holders for the renovated units.

[Nicole Morell]: The current Section 8 tenants are through the Arlington Housing Authority, and the landlord has been in touch with them to verify that everything that they did was legal.

[Nicole Morell]: The city director did not ask him about current or future rent rates, as they were focused on keeping Medford residents housed at this time.

[Nicole Morell]: And they just went out to note that they did flyer every door in the building with the flyers with regard to ABCD and the move in, move out program.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, if anyone didn't get that information, we can make sure that that gets to you.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, so any further questions we can relate to them and as fellow council just said, we, as a, we, as a body don't have any statutory power, but we can absolutely advocate.

[Nicole Morell]: We can reach out to, you know, the city departments.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think even though we don't have direct power in this situation,

[Nicole Morell]: As fellow Councilors said, you know, my heart breaks for you guys.

[Nicole Morell]: Like, this is stuff that we've been trying to stave off for the past two years and the housing market being what it is, we're unfortunately going to keep, you know, this is going to keep happening to our residents and it's not right.

[Nicole Morell]: we'll do what we can to stop it.

[Nicole Morell]: But unfortunately, we don't have a lot of power in this situation.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: And if I could, there is, you know, there is an assessment of different roads, but there is no

[Nicole Morell]: plan to fund the fixing of those different roads.

[Nicole Morell]: So we have an assessment of what shape our roads in which obviously many of us can see with our own eyes, but we do not have a plan to fund the necessary repairs.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Ike.

[Nicole Morell]: Shelley, does that address your question?

[Nicole Morell]: Do you have anything else you'd like to speak on?

[Nicole Morell]: No, thank you very much.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further public participation?

[Nicole Morell]: Seeing and hearing none, records.

[Nicole Morell]: Hearing 20-568,

[Nicole Morell]: Legal notice, City of Medford, Massachusetts, Medford City Council, Chapter 94, Zoning.

[Nicole Morell]: The Medford City Council shall conduct a public hearing in the Howard F. Alden Chambers at Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, and via Zoom on Tuesday, March 22, 2022.

[Nicole Morell]: A Zoom link should be posted no later than Friday, March 18, 2022, to consider the recommendations of the Community Development Board and to take the following actions with regard to the zoning ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: Delete existing ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: The intent is to delete the entire existing ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: article one in general, and replaced with a proposed ordinance the intent is to replace the entire existing ordinance section one purpose and authority, Madam President motion to waive the reading and have a brief synopsis from our legal counsel on the topic was from tonight to waive the reading, saying my Councilor car VL with a brief synopsis from our legal counsel.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah.

[Nicole Morell]: You withdraw your motion.

[Nicole Morell]: So we'll read it and then we'll also get a synopsis.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay, resuming.

[Nicole Morell]: Article two, administration and enforcement.

[Nicole Morell]: Article three, reserve.

[Nicole Morell]: Article four, use regulations.

[Nicole Morell]: Article five, signs.

[Nicole Morell]: Article six, site plan review.

[Nicole Morell]: Article seven, development linkage fees.

[Nicole Morell]: Article eight, vacant and foreclosing properties.

[Nicole Morell]: Article nine, inclusionary housing.

[Nicole Morell]: And then the zoning map.

[Nicole Morell]: So to replace the proposed ordinance, the intent is to replace the entire existing ordinance with section 1.0 purpose and authority, section 2.0 districts, section 3.0 use regulations, section 4.0 dimensional regulations, section 5.0 nonconforming uses and structures, section 6.0 general regulations, section 7.0 special regulations,

[Nicole Morell]: section 8.0 special residential regulations, section 9.0 special district regulations, section 10.0 development linkage fees, section 11.0 administration and enforcement, section 12.0 definitions, and the zoning map dated asterisks.

[Nicole Morell]: The most recent version of the document is available for view in the city clerk's office and online.

[Nicole Morell]: at the Google Drive account listed.

[Nicole Morell]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations or aids.

[Nicole Morell]: By order of the Medford City Council, signed Adam L. Hurtubise.

[Nicole Morell]: So, Attorney Boborowski, could you also provide us with a brief synopsis of what we're looking at here?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Attorney Brabrowski.

[Nicole Morell]: As this is a hearing, we will open the hearing for those in favor of the paper.

[Nicole Morell]: Is there anyone who would like to speak who is in favor of the paper, either online or in the chambers?

[Nicole Morell]: I can use the raise hand function.

[Nicole Morell]: Otherwise, I can also scan through.

[Nicole Morell]: Any further discussion on the Councilor?

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for the discussion with the council.

[Nicole Morell]: If I could just for a moment from the chair, I want to echo my fellow

[Nicole Morell]: and thanking former Councilor Beto for really getting us to this point where we could carry it across the finish line in this term.

[Nicole Morell]: We had countless meetings on this, all public meetings, and I think perhaps too often it's highlighted where we disagree in this body.

[Nicole Morell]: But if you attended any of these meetings, it was all of us digging our heels in and doing the work and having the important discussions and representing the interests of the city and finding common ground.

[Nicole Morell]: That happened among the council,

[Nicole Morell]: it happened as we work with the Community Development Board and it happened as you know we had the department heads come in and have discussions so that we could get a document that I think we're all proud of that really represents the work of the council.

[Nicole Morell]: We can get mired in lots of things but zoning is a major piece of the council and our responsibility and I think this is something that we're all proud of

[Nicole Morell]: and that we've all been able to have our hands on it and represent different points of view and move Medford forward and also act, as many have said, as a first step to the next thing.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm hoping that, you know, the administration was able to empower us with Attorney Bobrowski, and I hope that they will empower us and fund us to continue this work because it's important work and this is what we've just begun.

[Nicole Morell]: Vice-Presidents.

[Nicole Morell]: Uh, thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: 74-0 in the negative, the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: Motions, orders and resolutions.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-073, this is for me unless any councilors object, I think it's read from the chair.

[Nicole Morell]: report offered by President Morell be it so resolved that the city council approved and transmit to the general court for their consideration, the following home rule petition as originally introduced by the mayor, and as amended by the city council and committee of the whole.

[Nicole Morell]: and act authorizing the election of a charter commission in the city of Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Be enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives in general court assembled and by the authority of the same as follows.

[Nicole Morell]: Section one, notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws or the provisions of any general law, special law or regulation to the contrary, the city of Medford city council shall at the first regular city election or earlier occurring special election

[Nicole Morell]: held on or after the 60th day following the effective date of this act by order provides for election of a nine member charter commission.

[Nicole Morell]: Section two, the charter commission shall be composed of one commissioner elected from each of the eight wards of the city and one elected at large.

[Nicole Morell]: In the event of a charter commissioner elected to represent a particular ward should move within the city during their term of office, they may continue to serve as the representative from the ward from which they were elected.

[Nicole Morell]: The vacancy created by any commissioner who moves from the city during their term of office or who resigns may be filled by majority vote of the entire commission.

[Nicole Morell]: Section three, other than as set forth here in the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws shall be applicable to the nomination and election of charter commissioners and to the duties and responsibilities of the city and the charter commission elected here under.

[Nicole Morell]: Section four, this act shall take effect upon its passage.

[Nicole Morell]: As amended by the City Council and Committee of the Whole, President Morell moved to amend the language of the petition to fill any vacancy on the Charter Commission by replacing that member with the person who received the next highest number of votes for that position on the commission.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins second.

[Nicole Morell]: Approved on a roll call vote of six in favor and Councilor Caraviello abstaining because he had just arrived.

[Nicole Morell]: Is there any discussion from the Council on this paper?

[Nicole Morell]: Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: 10th regular meeting of the Medford City Council March 8 2022 is called to order.

[Nicole Morell]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Nicole Morell]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Nicole Morell]: If the Councilors don't mind I can read this from the chair I'm actually the first resolution or.

[Nicole Morell]: Hey, you want to come up.

[Nicole Morell]: 21-577 offered by President Burrell be it resolved that the city of Medford through its city council raised the maximum income level for clause 41 a of MGL chapter 59 section

[Nicole Morell]: the senior tax deferral to the amount established annually by the Commissioner of Revenue as to the income limit for single seniors who are not head of household to qualify under the senior circuit program.

[Nicole Morell]: As I mentioned last week, this is something we met with the whole about just the council has the power to set the maximum for seniors eligible for this program.

[Nicole Morell]: It's currently at $50,000.

[Nicole Morell]: The council has raised this a few times in recent years, and we met with the whole to discuss the idea of tying it to the senior

[Nicole Morell]: circuit breaker amount which is about set by the Commissioner of Revenue goes up a small amount each year to stay with inflation and other metrics so that number is just over 61,000 right now.

[Nicole Morell]: So this would tie that to this would tie our maximum to that number in perpetuity, unless we were to revisit as a council to adjust that amount so that is the resolution of any Councilors have any comments they would like to add.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you for the discussion on emotional Councilor Knight seconded by Vice President Bears Mr. Clerk, please actually know, we know we do need to call the role, because of this is a local option.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.

[Nicole Morell]: Yes.
