[Nicole Morell]: Requesting the appropriation of $100,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust for the Shepherd Brooks Manor East Elevation Restoration Project.

[Nicole Morell]: Requesting the appropriation of $50,000, $47,000 from CPA Historic Reserve, and $3,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the Cemetery Board of Trustees for the WPA Garage Study.

[Nicole Morell]: Requesting the appropriation of $400,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the Cemetery Board of Trustees slash Department of Veterans Affairs for the Oak Grove Cemetery World War I Memorial Restoration Project.

[Nicole Morell]: Requesting the appropriation of $17,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve for the Mayor's Office slash Parks Division for the Memorial Park Concession Stand slash Equipment Storage Project.

[Nicole Morell]: Requesting the appropriation of $20,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the Community Garden Commission for the McNally Community Garden Expansion Project.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-082 offered by Councilor Tseng and Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas residential streets between Main Street and Mystic Avenue, such as but not limited to Bonner Ave, Hancock Avenue, Billings Avenue, Golden Avenue, and Alexander Avenue are often used as cut through streets to bypass Harbor Street traffic and

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas residents in South Medford have raised questions and concerns about the speed of traffic, pedestrian safety, the quality of residential streets, and the city's temporary and permanent solutions.

[Nicole Morell]: And whereas mobile applications like Waze have exacerbated these issues, be it resolved that the Medford City Council investigate the questions, concerns, and issues listed above and ask the acting commissioner of public works and the traffic engineer for an update on strategies to address these issues.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it further resolved that the Medford City Council asked the Department of Public Works and the Engineering Department to consider repaving dilapidated residential streets used extensively by commuters to bypass Harvard Street traffic, adding do not block intersection signage and do not block the box road pains to the Bonner main intersection and implementing strategies to lessen traffic buildup at the intersection of Main Street and Harvard Street.

[Nicole Morell]: be it further resolved by the Medford City Council that this discussion be referred to the Subcommittee on Public Works and Utilities for further discussion with the Department of Public Works and Engineering Department heads.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative, the motion passes.

[Nicole Morell]: 22-083 offered by Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas the 2020 Massachusetts Uniform Citation Data Analysis Report, the report of projects supported by the Massachusetts Executive Office of Public Safety and Security suggests that there is a statistically significant correlation between race slash ethnicity

[Nicole Morell]: and step on stop outcomes in Medford, or black and Hispanic individuals are more likely to receive criminal citations or be arrested, and Hispanic individuals are less likely to receive written warnings and whereas the report states that there may be a multitude of explanations for these disparities, and how bias may be one among these many explanations

[Nicole Morell]: whereas the report strongly encourages reflection and conversation about the potential causes of these disparities to build and maintain community trust, which is paramount to our public safety.

[Nicole Morell]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council request that the Chief of Police investigate potential causes of stop outcome disparities and report back to the City Council on his findings, and be it further resolved that the Medford City Council ask the Medford Police Department to publish data on all motor vehicle stops, outcomes of searches, triggering offenses,

[Nicole Morell]: in the duration of stops, the data requests by researchers behind their fort, and post this data on its website.

[Nicole Morell]: And be it further resolved, the Medford City Council asks the Medford Police Department to consider holding a community forum on traffic stop issues in order to deepen community trust and public safety as recommended by the report.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Tseng.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Again- Councilor Caraviello has the floor.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Collins.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is a space, apologies, this is a space that Medford can be a leader in.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is a program that the state recently passed, something that I'm benefiting from right now that I'm on paid family leave through my day job at MIT and something that

[Nicole Morell]: I think through the political process, unfortunately, municipal employees were sacrificed.

[Nicole Morell]: The cities have to opt into this program.

[Nicole Morell]: Medford would be among the first.

[Nicole Morell]: I think one of the first, I think cities are looking at this.

[Nicole Morell]: They have the ability to opt in.

[Nicole Morell]: There's a lot of discussion.

[Nicole Morell]: There's an outline process to join this, but it would allow our municipal pool employees to have those same benefits that are being extended across the state.

[Nicole Morell]: And we've talked a lot about the value of our city employees.

[Nicole Morell]: We've talked a lot about attracting top talent,

[Nicole Morell]: And, you know, just valuing our employees as human beings with full lives.

[Nicole Morell]: And this is something that absolutely would affirm that, would give people the time off they need for expanding their family, for a sick family member, for all of the things outlined in paid family medical leave.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think this is something that we absolutely have to look into as a city because it's the right thing to do.

[Nicole Morell]: But also, as I said, it will attract talent.

[Nicole Morell]: It will give them the chance to be a leader.

[Nicole Morell]: So my motion, I would move to move this to committee of the whole,

[Nicole Morell]: invite, you know, the city solicitor, chief of staff, I think human resources to see how we can implement this as a city.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Vice President Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to thank

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Knight now I have a squiggly baby.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, this is something we discussed in April of 2020.

[Nicole Morell]: The council voted to raise this to $50,000 per year.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is a state program that the city engages in, and the city council has the ability to set the maximum income cap for people who can participate.

[Nicole Morell]: And it can be raised up to the senior circuit breaker number, which is adjusted every year.

[Nicole Morell]: When we discussed this back in April of 2020,

[Nicole Morell]: We're you know the council is rightfully concerned to see what we're going to get as far as real estate receipts and didn't want to raise this too high.

[Nicole Morell]: I believe Councilor Vice President Knight brought up the idea of just automatically tying it to the senior circuit breaker so we don't have to revisit this every so often as the state already adjusts that number reflective of cost of living.

[Nicole Morell]: This is a program that not a lot of people participate in, but for some people it is, you know, a lifesaver, a game changer program.

[Nicole Morell]: So I would just want to see that it be opened up to as many residents as possible.

[Nicole Morell]: But I mean, we're still talking single digits, I believe, as far as people who participate in the program.

[Nicole Morell]: I did ask Ellen for an updated number on number of participants.

[Nicole Morell]: I don't have that number just yet.

[Nicole Morell]: We do have time.

[Nicole Morell]: I believe this has to be set by April for the fiscal year 2023.

[Nicole Morell]: So if my fellow Councilors would like to see this as a committee of the whole, I'm more than happy to move it there.

[Nicole Morell]: But I think this is just a smart way to approach this program and then have it match that level set by the state.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: So Ben is the MIT System Design and Management Industry and Certificate Director and the 2021 awardee of the Collier Medal.

[Nicole Morell]: So MIT gives out a number of staff excellence awards each year, which are among the highest honors to staff.

[Nicole Morell]: As is the tradition, there's only one Collier Medal award winner.

[Nicole Morell]: And that's Ben, her Medford neighbor, Medford resident.

[Nicole Morell]: And the Collier Medal was established in 2014 to honor MIT police officer Sean Collier and his commitment to community engagement and model citizenship.

[Nicole Morell]: As I said, it's among the highest honors that MIT awards its staff and community members.

[Nicole Morell]: Ben was awarded this because in the spring of 2020, as the WHO declared COVID-19 to be an official pandemic and case numbers rose in Massachusetts, groups and individuals across MIT and the state sought ways to help

[Nicole Morell]: Ben's background in the medical device industry and his training in applying a systems approach to socio-technical challenges immediately proved useful.

[Nicole Morell]: And he worked closely with professors in the Department of Mechanical Engineering to navigate the rapidly evolving response across the Institute and identify labs and other groups that could join these efforts.

[Nicole Morell]: So through this work, Ben connected with the Massachusetts Technology Collaborative, who convened experts from a variety of fields to form what became the Massachusetts Manufacturing Emergency Response Team.

[Nicole Morell]: And this collaborative, which was cross-disciplinary and cross-industry,

[Nicole Morell]: played a key role in the Baker-Polito administration's initial response to COVID-19, and the Massachusetts Manufacturing Emergency Response Team helped local manufacturers pivot their operations to produce PPE and other much-needed supplies for healthcare workers at scale.

[Nicole Morell]: And Ben helped lead the effort to provide medical device development guidance to manufacturers, and he also served as the team's key liaison with FDA officials and ensured that critical emergency regulatory requirements were addressed.

[Nicole Morell]: So for these efforts, Ben was awarded the medal

[Nicole Morell]: And I want to just take a moment to recognize him for this tremendous achievement.

[Nicole Morell]: I know there are many, many Medford residents who contributed in many ways to the COVID-19 response, but I just want to call out this really high honor offered by MIT for his work across the state and just thank his neighbor, Laurel Ruma, for reaching out and ensuring that the community knows about one of its residents in this really important award.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to echo vice president.

[Nicole Morell]: This program would allow residents of private ways to file a permit notifying the city of the preferred tow company for that private way to tow away vehicles parked illegally on that private way.

[Nicole Morell]: I guess this is a program that's done in Somerville.

[Nicole Morell]: So this was brought to the council's attention by someone very near and dear to us all, Mr. Gordon, who helps to make these meetings possible and accessible.

[Nicole Morell]: So these bills, it's the identical bill.

[Nicole Morell]: I know they, identical docket number, docket.

[Nicole Morell]: I know that these haven't been assigned a bill just yet, but I think it's something that needs to come with our support early.

[Nicole Morell]: Essentially,

[Nicole Morell]: These are seeking to assess fees for streaming services that rely on digital infrastructure that's at least partially in public rights away.

[Nicole Morell]: And then a portion of funds collected in this way would go to the Commonwealth General Fund.

[Nicole Morell]: And most importantly, to municipalities proportionally based on population and to community centers proportionally based on population.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is really important at this time as more and more people cut the cord from cable and money to public education and government media gain through these agreements is really impacted as a result of those changes.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is really a measure to encourage our local delegation to support these.

[Nicole Morell]: And I did get word that Christine Barber did sign on as a co-sponsor after I submitted this item.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's really just to make sure we have the funding from these systems in place to continue to support our diverse community, robust and diverse community media, and to really respond to the changing behaviors of both providers and subscribers.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to read off a few stats in addition to what was worded in the resolution itself.

[Nicole Morell]: So the amount of carbon monoxide emitted from a typical backpack leaf blower for just one hour is equal to the amount of carbon monoxide coming from the tailpipe of a car operating for over eight hours.

[Nicole Morell]: that's going to be a lot of dust and particles in the air.

[Nicole Morell]: The floors push 300 to 700 cubic feet of air per minute at speeds of 150 to 280 miles per hour with the resulting dust containing particles that can include pollen, mold, animal feces, heavy metals, break lining powder and chemicals from herbicides and pesticides.

[Nicole Morell]: And for the user of a leaf blower, the noise

[Nicole Morell]: a lover that has been demonstrated to trigger increases in blood pressure and heart rates.

[Nicole Morell]: So these stats stand on their own, but the main reason I introduced this resolution is that I've heard from countless residents over the constant onslaught of leaf blowers year round with really, the only time these machines aren't being used is when there's snow on the ground.

[Nicole Morell]: So we have a little bit of respite right now.

[Nicole Morell]: And these residents aren't reaching out because they're disturbed by a leaf blower for an hour when the neighbor's yard crew comes because

[Nicole Morell]: they spend hours a day listening to yard crews that sometimes have three leaf blowers going at a time.

[Nicole Morell]: We know how big our lots are in Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: They're not that big, but I think they require three people simultaneously using a leaf blower.

[Nicole Morell]: And this, of course, is all happening while people are working remotely, while students are trying to learn remotely, while people are trying to sleep after working the night shift.

[Nicole Morell]: And also we spend a lot of our meetings talking about a respiratory disease that has gripped the world.

[Nicole Morell]: And a lot of these issues contribute to respiratory issues are exasperated by this gas-powered liquor use.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm not naive to the fact that I understand that sometimes this can be a controversial thing to raise.

[Nicole Morell]: But what I'm asking for here is to send this to the Environmental Affairs Subcommittee so that it can be studied.

[Nicole Morell]: you can hear from residents, people that would be affected by this, and look at, you know, regulations that are working in places like Arlington, Cambridge, Newton, and Brookline, and also look at other things that may exist, whether there's grant opportunities for incentivization for transitioning to electric leaf blowers, which are much less, obviously, you don't have the emissions, they're much quieter, and they operate in a slightly lower

[Nicole Morell]: speed.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm asking to move this to subcommittee to really work on this and see what's something that can work for as many people as possible.

[Nicole Morell]: But I cede to Councilor Bears.

[Nicole Morell]: on the dot and you guys don't want to hear me talk about plastics, forks and knives right now, but I agree with Councilor Bears that this is important.

[Nicole Morell]: The pandemic will recede, but the amount of single use and disposable items that has vastly increased because of the pandemic will not be gone anytime soon.

[Nicole Morell]: We can't avoid the use of PPE, but there are things like plastic utensils that

[Nicole Morell]: They take about a thousand years to break down if they ever do.

[Nicole Morell]: And I know many of us come home with plastic utensils from the takeout of restaurants in the area that we're trying to support that we simply don't need.

[Nicole Morell]: We have utensils at home.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think it's just a common sense resolution that just to minimize the amount of these that go out in takeaway bags that people may never use and just put in their drawers at home and eventually throw away and they end up in a landfill and never break down.

[Nicole Morell]: So I move approval on this kind of common sense measure.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: I mean, this is in direct response to just the increase of single-use plastics that's come as a result of COVID.

[Nicole Morell]: There's a lot of, you know, unfortunately the meals that are not being had inside of restaurants are being replaced, thankfully, by takeout.

[Nicole Morell]: And there's just, it's so much more plastic that does come with a cost.

[Nicole Morell]: It comes with a cost to all of us.

[Nicole Morell]: It comes with a cost to future Councilors introducing resolutions when these forks and spoons are on the felsway dumped in someone's yard and we want to have them cleaned up.

[Nicole Morell]: I mean, I think it's, this is actually a fairly, some ordering services, this is a common selection.

[Nicole Morell]: You can select whether or not to have utensils.

[Nicole Morell]: I know a few establishments I frequent in Medford actually do have this option, and it would be something that, again, just guidance, I imagine this is guidance as well, but something that when you're placing an order, someone on the phone says, okay, do you need utensils with that, as opposed to just,

[Nicole Morell]: Throwing a fistful in but again, this is not something that we have the ability to really

[Nicole Morell]: It's not something we really have the ability to enforce, of course, but I think having guidance that people can look to and say, okay, this is probably just a way to minimize waste.

[Nicole Morell]: I think it's, is there a direct response to the way the pandemic has reshaped the, and really to push back a lot of advances we have made in reusables and now has really increased the amount of plastic trash we're seeing, you know, as a community globally, everywhere.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: I mean, I would hope that $40 million counts as substantial rehabilitation.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: And then my final question, if the chief of staff could confirm this, and I did, I had the opportunity to speak with Maria yesterday as well.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: That's all I have.

[Nicole Morell]: I don't know if this is a question for you or the administration.

[Nicole Morell]: Does council approval of this, is it a simple majority or two thirds vote?

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to thank Councilor Knight for bringing this forward.

[Nicole Morell]: Tree canopies are a moving target with development, disease, and age.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, this is just a simple request.

[Nicole Morell]: So this roadmap lays out a number of goals, and I just think it would be beneficial for the council and of course,

[Nicole Morell]: the residents of Medford to get an update on some of the progress towards the goals outlined in the report.

[Nicole Morell]: I do want to note that shortly after submitting this item, I did get in the mail an update on that SNAP gap study, which is a reference.

[Nicole Morell]: And I just want to highlight something from that.

[Nicole Morell]: So this was completed by the Medford Food Security Task Force.

[Nicole Morell]: And so for those who don't know, the SNAP gap, it refers to the difference between the number of low-income mass residents receiving mass health who may be eligible for SNAP

[Nicole Morell]: and those who are actually registered for SNAP.

[Nicole Morell]: And the gap between those two numbers is 46% at the state level, and it's been found to be 63% at the city level.

[Nicole Morell]: So I just want to note that because this is a number that's always crucial, but as the pandemic rages on and ravages people's livelihoods with no federal aid at this point, it's a particular problem at this time.

[Nicole Morell]: So I really thank the Food Security Task Force for their work on this.

[Nicole Morell]: And the whole report is on the city website at this point,

[Nicole Morell]: which I think is just really helpful for people to know how this is being tackled with regards to the social justice roadmap, but just in general as this work is always important and ongoing.

[Nicole Morell]: So this is almost six months ago, and one key tenant of this pledge, which was formed to drive communities, it was formed to drive communities, and I quote, to engage in a public review of its policing policies and result in potential reform.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think like an FAQ document might be a good A good thing to do anyway.

[Nicole Morell]: Sure, so what I have here is

[Nicole Morell]: Information on what the recommended process would be for lining all of our different development review items up.

[Nicole Morell]: The best opportunity for the community development board to weigh in or participate in this process.

[Nicole Morell]: Some more information that he mentioned he was going to look into on demolition delay and the historic process and how that fits in with his proposed changes.

[Nicole Morell]: Any opportunities for cross-reference to the City's Solar Ordinance?

[Nicole Morell]: Opportunities to encourage energy efficiency and green building standards in the Zoning Ordinance?

[Nicole Morell]: To what extent does he recommend design guidelines or a design review process?

[Nicole Morell]: Should this be incorporated into the Ordinance or should we do it some other way?

[Nicole Morell]: And the wording of neighborhood character and social structures.

[Nicole Morell]: and concerns about that and why he uses that.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: I raised this at this time, make this request based on a number of things we've been talking about recently.

[Nicole Morell]: And I do want to point out the fact that I know our engineering department and DPW does great work on updating our sidewalks and bringing them into compliance as intersections and sidewalks are updated, projects happen.

[Nicole Morell]: But we've been having a lot of discussions.

[Nicole Morell]: I know Councilor Behr has introduced

[Nicole Morell]: and resolution last week, looking at our snow removal ordinance.

[Nicole Morell]: And Councilor Knight brought up a number of salient points as far as the massive amount of work that our DPW has already and really could be doing to improve accessibility in our community.

[Nicole Morell]: And we've also had a number of discussions with a fine point on equity in the past several months.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think when we're looking at all of these things, we have to consider our streets and our sidewalks and accessibility issues and whether or not they're actually accessible and equitable to everyone in our community.

[Nicole Morell]: I know the ADA is essentially an unfunded mandate, so it's really challenging for cities to do the amount of work that needs to be done to make sure our streets and our sidewalks are accessible to everyone.

[Nicole Morell]: But I think it's really important as we come around the calendar and start looking at another budget time to understand where we stand as a city as far as accessibility with our sidewalks and what work there is, also possibly what grants we've already pursued and plans to update as far as

[Nicole Morell]: complete updates that sidewalks will be brought into compliance because it's a massive project, but also looking at those sidewalks individually.

[Nicole Morell]: So I'm just really trying to gather information so we can make the best decisions come budget time and making sure we're supporting work that really needs to be done in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: So I move approval.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: So I've had a number of members from Medford's art community reach out about this.

[Nicole Morell]: So the idea behind these percent for arts programs

[Nicole Morell]: which are usually put in place via ordinance is for community benefit and enrichment by having a decided upon percent of construction costs or fees of municipal capital investment to be designated for use for public artwork.

[Nicole Morell]: So simple, they allocate a small portion of capital construction renovation budgets or something of the like for purchase, commissioning and installation of artworks that would be in the public space.

[Nicole Morell]: So let's see.

[Nicole Morell]: Prior to endorsement, any changes must be shown on a revised subdivision plan, including a summary of conditions.

[Nicole Morell]: The subdivision shall comply with all applicable standards and regulations as set forth in the Community Development Board Rules and Regulations, except for those for which a waiver has been approved.

[Nicole Morell]: Consistent with Mass General Law, Chapter 41, Section 81U, after the expiration of 20 days without notice of appeal to Superior Court or Land Court,

[Nicole Morell]: The board shall endorse the plan.

[Nicole Morell]: This endorsement shall occur following the provision of a performance guarantee in accordance with Mass General Law, Chapter 41, Section 81U, in an amount determined by the city engineer and approved by the board.

[Nicole Morell]: Said amount shall bear a direct reasonable relationship to the expected cost of the work, including inflation necessary to complete the work.

[Nicole Morell]: The amount shall be revised from time to time on recommendation of the city engineer to reflect the remaining cost of the work.

[Nicole Morell]: construction of the subdivision improvements shall be completed within two years of the date of endorsement of the plans by the board.

[Nicole Morell]: And this project is subject to linkage fees, city of Medford zoning ordinance chapter 94 sections 94382.

[Nicole Morell]: And in terms of conditions recommended by

[Nicole Morell]: City staff compliance with conditions recommended by Timothy McGivern, city engineer, in a letter to the board dated August 18th, 2020.

[Nicole Morell]: She did not submit a new one, but she has expressed that her conditions still apply.

[Nicole Morell]: One of them is to submit a written plan for proper dust remediation.

[Nicole Morell]: One of them is a detailed solid waste plan must be submitted to the board of health and that dumpster permits must be obtained for any dumpsters prior to construction beginning.

[Nicole Morell]: and another that integrated pest management is required.

[Nicole Morell]: And she goes into more detail on each of those in her letter.

[Nicole Morell]: And the first two are,

[Nicole Morell]: My understanding and Tim's comment number 47 on this is that the proponent will be working with the engineering department and the DPW to address concerns about the water main.

[Nicole Morell]: So that takes care of his first two comments that were about his uncertainty about the water main.

[Nicole Morell]: Hydrant locations will be determined by the fire department, noting that one hydrant must be on Winthrop Street.

[Nicole Morell]: The minimum water main size is eight inch ductile piping and one inch copper services into the 10 residential lots.

[Nicole Morell]: We'll also maintain a loop system around the property adhering to the 10 foot water and sewer separation.

[Nicole Morell]: All standard testing for pressure and bacteria shall be in accordance with the DEP and AWWA standard.

[Nicole Morell]: Water mains that intersect with other water main piping to the triple gated and open to the right

[Nicole Morell]: All water services will be placed in the sidewalk with shutoffs off the property line.

[Nicole Morell]: All service connection on the old six inch water main will be replaced with one inch copper to the property line with new shutoffs.

[Nicole Morell]: All as built will be reviewed by water and sewer and the engineering divisions.

[Nicole Morell]: Any work performed on water and sewer must be inspected before backfilling.

[Nicole Morell]: Emergency phone numbers must be provided prior to any work being done on roads in Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: Drawings and pre-construction meetings are advised.

[Nicole Morell]: Any contractor working on water services must be a certified drain layer licensed with the city of Medford.

[Nicole Morell]: and these are all items that were responded to by Mr. Champion, I believe had all been resolved, correct?

[Nicole Morell]: Except for the water main that you were working with the city to accommodate.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, I wanna thank Councilor Bears for bringing this forward.

[Nicole Morell]: I have a few comments on this if I could just read them off.

[Nicole Morell]: So some people will say this is symbolism, and I definitely agree.

[Nicole Morell]: It's symbolic of the commitments that we've made as a city, and this is the easy thing.

[Nicole Morell]: If we can't do the easy thing, how will we do the hard work?

[Nicole Morell]: How will we ensure that in 5, 10, 15, 25, 50 years, we're not right back here having done nothing of substance and learned nothing?

[Nicole Morell]: So the uncomfortable truth is that for far too long, this country has said that Black lives do not matter.

[Nicole Morell]: Their disparate health outcomes, their housing discrimination, and unequal rates of school suspension, arrests, and imprisonment.

[Nicole Morell]: We say they do not matter.

[Nicole Morell]: We said they do not matter by saying that all men are created equal, but in fact, not meaning Black men.

[Nicole Morell]: So through chattel slavery, segregation, limiting voting rights, and Jim Crow, we have said that black lives do not matter, which is why we must now state unequivocally that black lives do matter.

[Nicole Morell]: To say so is not a political act.

[Nicole Morell]: It's a statement of human rights.

[Nicole Morell]: We've declared systemic racism a public health crisis in this city.

[Nicole Morell]: And perhaps if we have a reminder in front of city hall every day, we will make good on the work that is needed to actually address this crisis.

[Nicole Morell]: And for this, I support this measure.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: Hello?

[Nicole Morell]: I just found her and unmuted her.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Laurel.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: I just want to reiterate my point that this is not a political statement.

[Nicole Morell]: This is about human rights.

[Nicole Morell]: The Office of Special Counsel found that Black Lives Matter is not a political statement.

[Nicole Morell]: And to say that it is a political statement is something that you're able to do when your life, your lived experience, your day in, day out is not impacted.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's a privilege to be able to say, hey, that's political.

[Nicole Morell]: Whereas for everyone else, for the people affected, it's a human right.

[Nicole Morell]: So thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: Yep.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: Okay.

[Nicole Morell]: And both of those are for the 10-lot subdivision at 541 and 551 Winthrop Street.

[Nicole Morell]: The original hearing was opened on May 15th, 2019 and was continued to September 11th, 2019 at the request of the applicant so that he could respond to questions by several department heads in their review of the project.

[Nicole Morell]: At the September hearing, the board found that information necessary to ensure the access for public safety vehicles and the provision of proper utilities to ensure adequate water for domestic and firefighting purposes, sewage and storm drainage was deficient and thus the definitive subdivision plan was denied.

[Nicole Morell]: The board also found that the site plan review application did not meet site plan review standards relative to imposing undue burden on sewers, sanitary, storm drains, water distribution systems, or similar public facilities that could have been avoided by modification to the plans and the special permit for site plan review was denied.

[Nicole Morell]: This decision was appealed by the applicant and the project was remanded back to the community development board to hold a new public hearing in light of additional information submitted

[Nicole Morell]: for consideration by the board.

[Nicole Morell]: And so revised materials were submitted to the board in June.

[Nicole Morell]: City departments reviewed and made some comments on that.

[Nicole Morell]: And the proponent is requesting that the board reduce that bond amount.

[Nicole Morell]: They requested that it be reduced down to $27,774.

[Nicole Morell]: And the city engineer performed a site visit and a review of their reduction request.

[Nicole Morell]: And his estimate came back at $38,126.

[Nicole Morell]: So he'd like the city to hold on to a little bit more funding or bond amount than what the proponent had requested.

[Nicole Morell]: He said that this estimate includes a 20% contingency, but this amount could be adjusted at the discretion of the board if you would like.

[Nicole Morell]: So the board is being asked to vote whether to approve or deny this bond reduction and sort of what the amount would be.

[Nicole Morell]: But the city engineer's estimate is for 38,126.

[Nicole Morell]: And the second part of this is that

[Nicole Morell]: The proponent had asked for the board's opinion on whether they could pursue full building permits.

[Nicole Morell]: And I did get the city engineer's take on that.

[Nicole Morell]: And he said, I take no exception to releasing the lots for full building permits.

[Nicole Morell]: In fact, I prefer it.

[Nicole Morell]: It is nice to have the houses built prior to final paving.

[Nicole Morell]: It also gives the binder a time to settle in reducing things like potholes and sub-base related cracking in the finish.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's just sort of an update on that.

[Nicole Morell]: Sorry.

[Nicole Morell]: So the main comments that I incorporated, um, were around sort of language tweaks.

[Nicole Morell]: And one of the things was bringing in some language about, um,

[Nicole Morell]: looking at the city's project review and the permitting processes and things like that.

[Nicole Morell]: So I tried to expand some of the areas to include that so that when the consultants come back, they'll know that they're looking at that as well, rather than just making a plan and looking at the zoning.

[Nicole Morell]: We also want to understand the city's processes and what is included in that.

[Nicole Morell]: I added some language around

[Nicole Morell]: strengthening that public outreach piece and the public participation and really marketing the plan and making that a focus of how do we get responses from the community and how do we make sure all different parts of the community know that this is happening and are able to participate.

[Nicole Morell]: I added some language that Christy sent about broad goals.

[Nicole Morell]: And maybe I can actually just read those two.

[Nicole Morell]: There are a few different areas where the RFP talks about goals and things, but this was an interesting sort of overarching goals of both the comprehensive plan and the phase two that would look at kind of the zoning and the processes.

[Nicole Morell]: And it's to document a clear vision, connect a public investment in that vision.

[Nicole Morell]: connect regulation to that vision, create a roadmap for thinking and acting from a comprehensive perspective and providing an excellent system for project review.

[Nicole Morell]: So kind of bringing that comprehensive plan from theoretical down to like, what does this mean systems wise in the city?

[Nicole Morell]: So those were sort of, and then some changes to some wording around placemaking, walkability, things like that.

[Nicole Morell]: We have an online permitting system.

[Nicole Morell]: The city launched it right at the start of COVID.

[Nicole Morell]: Right now, it's mainly just being used for building permits.

[Nicole Morell]: it will be built out at some point to encompass the rest of it, but right, that's still sort of in flux, in process.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's, I could mention that specifically if you want, but there is a software that the building department has committed to and is being trained on and the other department heads are being trained on.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think that's sort of in progress.

[Nicole Morell]: That is also in progress.

[Nicole Morell]: The assessor's office is, there's a consulting firm making that for them.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, so that's in progress.

[Nicole Morell]: And then I would assume that part of since phase one is sort of the comprehensive plan and phase two is more looking at the

[Nicole Morell]: the vision and goals from the comprehensive plan.

[Nicole Morell]: What do we need to change in the zoning?

[Nicole Morell]: What do we need to change in our processes to get there?

[Nicole Morell]: And so that I would envision would include an update to that digital zoning map to reflect any zoning changes.

[Nicole Morell]: But also the engineering department will sort of take ownership of that map once it exists.

[Nicole Morell]: It'll be a GIS layer that can actually be edited and changed and exists already.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, I guess there's sort of two terms.

[Nicole Morell]: In my mind, there's like the term

[Nicole Morell]: of like when you do the plan, but if it should be looking farther than that, I guess.

[Nicole Morell]: There was some language about 10 to 20 years.

[Nicole Morell]: That's something that I think if you guys have any input on, but there might be some things that wouldn't necessarily happen in 10 years that you might wanna start initial steps for or be planning for in a comprehensive plan, maybe.

[Nicole Morell]: I can take a stab at adding some language about what I'm hearing is...

[Nicole Morell]: It'd be kind of a 10-year plan, but with a piece that is looking long-term, a long-term visioning piece that really focuses on where do we want to be in 30 years or so, and takes into account climate and key development areas and all of that.

[Nicole Morell]: But the plan itself and the action items would be focused on that 10-year timeframe.

[Nicole Morell]: Other things to emphasize will be making sure the plan has key performance indicators or some way to measure the success of implementation over time.

[Nicole Morell]: Am I missing anything?

[Nicole Morell]: So I could try to add some of that language in, send out the link again when that's been done and maybe give you guys a week or so to review it and send me any final comments.

[Nicole Morell]: And with the expectation that we would put this out prior to the next meeting, so we wouldn't have another group conversation about it.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: And thank you, Councilor Bears for putting so much of that into a statement and putting it so well.

[Nicole Morell]: So you alluded to this, but I'm gonna start by reading off a few statistics.

[Nicole Morell]: So black Americans are nearly three times more likely than white Americans to be killed by police.

[Nicole Morell]: Black women die of pregnancy related causes at a rate about three times higher than those of white women.

[Nicole Morell]: Black Americans are dying of COVID-19 at a three times rate of white Americans.

[Nicole Morell]: And black Americans face a higher risk of particle pollution than white Americans, which recent research has shown ties into the severity of COVID-19 cases.

[Nicole Morell]: All of this does nothing to speak of the immense mental health toll of systemic and structural racism on black Americans.

[Nicole Morell]: These are just a few highlights of the so-called social determinants of health.

[Nicole Morell]: So to me, as has been referenced already by Councilor Bears, it's incredibly apparent that structural and systemic racism is a public health crisis.

[Nicole Morell]: Saying so follows in line with statements of the American Medical Association, the American College of Physicians, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the American Public Health Association.

[Nicole Morell]: However, simply naming this emergency does not get the work done.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm committed, as I hope are my council colleagues,

[Nicole Morell]: to work within our power and alongside our colleagues on the school committee and in the administration to work within our system and our structures to break down the systemic and structural racism that exists within this city and within this country.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think the mayor, I had a line about us not being able to advance this work on our own.

[Nicole Morell]: So I thank the mayor for coming out and supporting this statement.

[Nicole Morell]: And that will allow us to dedicate resources and time to eradicate this issue.

[Nicole Morell]: And I also speak to the fact that I received probably more than 100 emails from community members around this, from residents seeking change and conversations that have needed to happen for decades that we cannot and should not ignore any longer.

[Nicole Morell]: So again, this resolution is not the work.

[Nicole Morell]: It's asking for the work to begin and inviting our colleagues throughout city government to work on this intractable challenge.

[Nicole Morell]: And I ask my fellow Councilors to support this resolution.

[Nicole Morell]: And again, I thank the mayor for coming out with her declaration.

[Nicole Morell]: So I just want to note and really reiterate that House Bill 440 urges the Massachusetts legislature to take action to pass a measure to enable independent public retirement systems to use their prudent judgment in regards to fossil fuel divestment.

[Nicole Morell]: So it's important to note that this body's support of the bill does not codify any action by the city, but it simply expresses our support of a bill that would allow us to divest from fossil fuels at some time in the future, should we choose to do so.

[Nicole Morell]: So I bring this forth, Councilor Bears and I bring this forth at the behest of many citizens that have reached out in the city of Medford, and a number of which are actually in the retirement system in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: By de facto investing our retirement funds in fossil fuels, we tacitly support emissions that contribute to climate change and all the damage associated with it, including air pollution and any issues and ailments caused by it.

[Nicole Morell]: And I think it's, we as a city,

[Nicole Morell]: It's very hard for us to work towards climate change adaptation and mitigation in one office while we invest in the very industry that's caused the need for such things in another.

[Nicole Morell]: So the current crisis also highlights just how vulnerable and sensitive our systems are.

[Nicole Morell]: And we can't continue to invest in a system that damages the very planet we live on and exacerbates all natural crises.

[Nicole Morell]: And that's kind of my stump for that.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Perak.

[Nicole Morell]: As I understand Perak,

[Nicole Morell]: In a previous decision brought forth from the Somerville City Council, and I know there are actually people on this call who are very well versed in that, they advised against it, but they actually, at a later date, they went back on that decision, I believe, or just decided that it was actually not the best advisement as far as ways to invest.

[Nicole Morell]: So because that independent board had advised against it,

[Nicole Morell]: they were, the Somerville City Council was unable to pass their measure.

[Nicole Morell]: And that's why this has come up in this form, because I see Councilor Scarpelli has his hand raised.

[Nicole Morell]: If people can offer, yeah, I mean, that's my poor retelling of it, so.

[Nicole Morell]: Yeah, thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: So this isn't just like a feel good kind of, so Bill, I mean, it does feel good, but the boards do need specific legislative authority because the way it is designed, and I do know that there are people on the call that can speak to this,

[Nicole Morell]: So if they fall under these categories, they can expect that we can act on it as required by law as opposed to

[Nicole Morell]: issue of another sort that we might not even be, we can deliberate on, but the action we can take is limited to, you know, maybe asking the administration to do something.

[Nicole Morell]: It's not under our purview by law.

[Nicole Morell]: I have a number of concerns with this text amendment.

[Nicole Morell]: I understand your request to send to the building commissioner, but I see it as being overly broad and really runs the risk of implying that the public asset of street parking is actually owned by individuals who are closest to it, which, of course, is not the case.

[Nicole Morell]: By adding curb cuts, we are further limiting parking, and with this being overly broad, it's unclear.

[Nicole Morell]: Does someone several houses down from where this was taken, if they haven't had parking in front of their house for decades, are they allowed to apply for this?

[Nicole Morell]: But none of this speaks to the fact that this would have an environmental impact.

[Nicole Morell]: It would increase the amount of impervious surface in the city.

[Nicole Morell]: Pervious surface and green infrastructure such as trees and dirt and soil are really important to mitigate the amount of stormwater drain off that goes into the Mystic River.

[Nicole Morell]: We already have flooding issues in the city by adding more pavement.

[Nicole Morell]: We run the risk of exacerbating them.

[Nicole Morell]: I do worry that also because of this, mature and significant trees will be under threat as people seek to make space to lay down asphalt.

[Nicole Morell]: I also have concerns that the buffer zones referenced are too vague.

[Nicole Morell]: You can look around the city at buffer zones that already exist.

[Nicole Morell]: There's maybe some mulch, maybe one tiny bush.

[Nicole Morell]: This definitely looks to

[Nicole Morell]: Kind of impact neighbors who are around that suddenly their neighbors are parking with their headlights on what was formerly a front yard.

[Nicole Morell]: They have headlights in their window.

[Nicole Morell]: And then also, often we talk about beautification in this chamber and beautification of the city.

[Nicole Morell]: And while I know beauty is in the eye of the beholder, I feel that parking on your front lawn, adding asphalt to formerly green,

[Nicole Morell]: And green infrastructure hardly goes far in the way of beautification of this city.

[Nicole Morell]: So as I said, I have a number of concerns on this proposed text amendment.

[Nicole Morell]: So the current minimum for Medford is actually $40,000.

[Nicole Morell]: Adjusted the interest rate and also at some point that cap was adjusted I found some pages on the website that need to be updated with the current cap But even at that level of $40,000 for the income cap Medford still lags behind surrounding cities in this state program So for people that don't know this is a state program that Medford takes part in that allows residents who meet certain criteria And are over the age of 65 to defer their property taxes until their house is sold or they pass away

[Nicole Morell]: Medford like every other municipality has to set an income cap on this and an interest rate as I said The interest rate was lower to 5% last session and I think the members of this body who helped to pass that But in regards to the income cap at $40,000 For context Somerville's limit is 57,000 Cambridge is 53,000 and it should be noted that both of these communities have owner occupied exemptions, which we do not have in Medford, so I

[Nicole Morell]: As far as kind of tools in our tools box to help people who need it to get relief from their property taxes were really limited.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think it's important that we make sure we're at the highest level allowed by the state so that as many people who do wish to take part in this program can.

[Nicole Morell]: Believe only two households currently take part in the program.

[Nicole Morell]: in their city is for people who meet the requirements with income not exceeding the state cap calculated under Clause 41A of Section 5 of Chapter 59.

[Nicole Morell]: To really kind of echo what Councilor Marks was saying, when we look at these signaling issues, making sure we're thinking beyond the cars, there are people on foot, they're on bikes.

[Nicole Morell]: And as traffic builds up, people tend to make hasty decisions that make it even more tricky for people to get through crosswalks, to get through on bikes.

[Nicole Morell]: So just ensure that we're looking at really a holistic approach to safety in these intersections.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: OK, thank you.

[Nicole Morell]: I'm pretty sure it's a lime bike I just drove by last night.

[Nicole Morell]: Councilor Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, I'd like to echo a few of the points made by Councilor Marks, you know, really just that lead time because of the weekend, having that extra time to understand the agenda.

[Nicole Morell]: A lot of times the agendas are written in a way that if you don't come to council meetings regularly, it can seem like a different language.

[Nicole Morell]: So taking the time to really understand and absorb what's actually going to come before the council.

[Nicole Morell]: Um, and I think Councilor Marks for bringing up childcare and the coordination that needs to go into that.

[Nicole Morell]: A lot of times women are the primary caregivers, and when you limit the planning time for child care, you look who can actually come out and speak on an issue.

[Nicole Morell]: Something that actually hasn't been mentioned is Tuesday nights, all the city hall staff is already home, so you have those parking spaces.

[Nicole Morell]: Wednesday nights, if you move the meetings, then the parking lot is full, you have a contentious issue.

[Nicole Morell]: People who maybe are waffling about coming to a meeting, they see the lot's full, they leave, they don't come in.

[Nicole Morell]: So that's something we have to consider.

[Nicole Morell]: And then going back to the point of resolutions under suspension, that happens under the purview of this body.

[Nicole Morell]: So even beyond setting a rule, it's up to the discretion of each and every Councilor here.

[Nicole Morell]: So having that discretion, deciding, you know, there is stuff that's gonna be timely that you want to bring up that very night.

[Nicole Morell]: but a lot of times it can wait to be put on the agenda.

[Nicole Morell]: So I think that's just things to think about and why Tuesday might, you know, may work better historically and now and going forward.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[Nicole Morell]: Thank you.
